Checking anti–JCV antibody status before initiating natalizumab is the cornerstone of PML risk mitigation. The STRATIFY JCV® ELISA accurately classifies patients into seropositive and seronegative groups. Bloomgren et al. (NEJM 2012) demonstrated a 6-fold higher PML incidence in JCV-positive patients after 24 months; JCV index >1.5 further stratifies high risk. The 2020 AAN guidelines recommend baseline and semiannual anti-JCV testing (Level B evidence). While extended-interval dosing (EID) reduces PML risk (Curran et al., MSJ 2021), initial screening remains mandatory. Imaging surveillance (MRI) and CSF PCR are diagnostic tools, not preventive measures. CT lacks sensitivity for white matter lesions; drug “holidays” risk MS rebound without proven PML benefit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Serial MRI
– MRI detects early PML lesions (T2/FLAIR hyperintensities, no mass effect) but does not prevent viral reactivation.
– Misconception: surveillance equals prevention.
– Differentiator: MRI is secondary surveillance; screening for JCV serostatus is primary risk reduction.

C. CT without contrast
– CT is insensitive to demyelinating white matter changes; PML lesions often invisible.
– Misconception: CT can replace MRI in demyelinating disease.
– Differentiator: CT lacks the resolution to detect subcortical demyelination.

D. Periods of drug wash out
– “Drug holidays” may precipitate MS rebound and have unproven PML risk reduction.
– Misconception: interrupting therapy reduces viral reactivation.
– Differentiator: continuous therapy with risk stratification is safer than unscheduled washouts.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-JCV Serology (A)Serial MRI (B)CT without Contrast (C)Drug Wash Out (D)
Primary PurposeRisk stratificationEarly detectionStructural imaging (low res.)Theoretical risk reduction
Prevents Viral ReactivationYesNoNoNo
Evidence LevelAAN Level B; STRATIFY studySupportive surveillanceNot recommendedNot recommended
DrawbacksRequires semiannual retestCosts, false positivesLow sensitivityRebound MS risk

Clinical Pearls

• Anti-JCV index >1.5 signals high PML risk; consider alternative therapies.
• Extended-interval natalizumab dosing (6-week infusions) lowers PML risk by ~60% without major efficacy loss.
• Abrupt natalizumab discontinuation can cause severe rebound MS activity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating MRI surveillance with true prevention of JCV reactivation.
2. Believing CT scans are adequate for demyelinating lesion detection.
3. Assuming drug holidays reduce PML risk—ignores rebound risk and lacks data.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AAN Practice Guideline (2020): Recommend baseline and semiannual anti-JCV antibody testing for all natalizumab patients (Level B).
• ECTRIMS/EAN Consensus (2019): Endorse JCV index quantification and consider EID as a risk mitigation strategy (Level II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

JCV infects oligodendrocytes in subcortical white matter—commonly parieto-occipital regions—leading to multifocal demyelination without mass effect.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Latent JCV in kidneys and lymphoid tissue reactivates under impaired CNS immune surveillance (e.g., natalizumab blockade of α4β1 integrin), allowing the virus to cross an intact blood–brain barrier and lyse oligodendrocytes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Baseline anti-JCV antibody status and index.
2. Assess prior immunosuppressant exposure and treatment duration.
3. Semiannual anti-JCV retesting.
4. MRI every 6–12 months for seropositive patients or new symptoms.

Neuroimaging Pearls

PML on MRI: T2/FLAIR hyperintense, often subcortical, no edema or mass effect, may show punctate “milky way” lesions early.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Natalizumab binds α4-integrin, preventing lymphocyte CNS entry; PML risk arises from reduced immune surveillance. EID and JCV serostatus guide therapy continuation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Risk mitigation via anti-JCV antibody testing is frequently tested as a core safety strategy in multiple sclerosis management.

question_text: For patients who cannot tolerate high-dose corticosteroids or have refractory disease, which of the following treatments is an alternative?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Autoimmune neurologic disorders (e.g., neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder, myasthenia gravis) often require high-dose corticosteroids for acute exacerbations. Key principles:
• B-cell–mediated pathology: CD20⁺ B-lymphocytes produce pathogenic autoantibodies.
• Corticosteroids modulate transcription factors (e.g., NF-κB) to suppress widespread inflammation but cause significant systemic toxicity.
• Steroid-sparing alternatives include antimetabolites (azathioprine, mycophenolate) and targeted biologics (rituximab) with more precise immune modulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rituximab, a chimeric anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, depletes circulating B cells within 2–4 weeks, reducing autoantibody titers and relapse rates. In a landmark cohort study (Pittock et al., Neurology 2015), rituximab lowered annualized relapse rate in AQP4-IgG–positive NMOSD from 2.3 to 0.3 (p<0.001). The 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis guidelines endorse rituximab as a maintenance option (Level C evidence). In refractory myasthenia gravis, the 2022 AAN practice update recommends rituximab for MuSK-antibody-positive patients (Level B). Rituximab’s targeted B-cell depletion offers a rapid, potent alternative when corticosteroids are not tolerated or insufficient.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Infliximab
• Incorrect because anti–TNF-α agents can precipitate or worsen demyelinating events.
• Misconception: “All biologics equally suppress neuroinflammation.”
• Differentiator: TNF blockade is contraindicated in demyelinating disorders.

C. Mycophenolate mofetil
• Incorrect as monotherapy for acute steroid-refractory relapses due to slow onset (3–6 months).
• Misconception: “Antimetabolites act rapidly in acute attacks.”
• Differentiator: Requires prolonged titration; not ideal for immediate control.

D. Azathioprine
• Incorrect for acute management due to similar delayed efficacy (3–6 months) and hepatotoxicity risk.
• Misconception: “Thiopurines can substitute steroids acutely.”
• Differentiator: Slow onset and dose-related cytopenias limit use in rapid relapse control.

Comparison Table

DrugMechanismOnset of EffectTypical IndicationKey Risks
RituximabAnti-CD20 B-cell depletion2–4 weeksNMOSD maintenance; refractory MGInfusion reactions; infections
InfliximabAnti–TNF-α1–2 weeksRefractory neurosarcoidosisDemyelination; infection
Mycophenolate mofetilIMPDH inhibitor (lymphocyte CNI)3–6 monthsNMOSD/AAV maintenanceGI upset; leukopenia
AzathioprinePurine analog (6-MP prodrug)3–6 monthsNMOSD/MG maintenanceHepatotoxicity; cytopenias

Clinical Pearls

- Monitor CD19⁺ and CD27⁺ B-cell counts to guide rituximab redosing and minimize relapse risk.
• Pre-infusion steroids and antihistamines reduce rituximab-associated infusion reactions.
• In NMOSD, early initiation of rituximab can preserve disability and prevent accrual of new lesions on MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all steroid-sparing agents work immediately—antimetabolites (azathioprine, mycophenolate) require months to become therapeutic.
2. Believing TNF inhibitors are universally safe in neuroimmunology—these can unmask or worsen demyelination.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Panel for NMO Diagnosis (IPND), 2015: “Recommend rituximab as maintenance therapy in AQP4-IgG NMOSD” (Level C evidence).
• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Myasthenia Gravis Update, 2022: “Rituximab advised for MuSK-positive myasthenia gravis refractory to first-line agents” (Level B evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Rituximab dosing: 1,000 mg IV on days 1 and 15, repeated every 6 months or guided by B-cell repopulation.
• Monitor CBC, immunoglobulins, and hepatitis B serologies prior to initiation.
• Screen for latent infections (TB, hepatitis) and administer prophylaxis as indicated.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Autoimmune neuroimmunology therapeutics frequently appear as single-best-answer vignettes, emphasizing mechanism of action, onset of effect, and safety profiles.

question_text: Q159. A young female treated for confirmed HSV presents with behavioral changes, a normal MRI of the brain, and focal facial myoclonic seizures. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] - HSV encephalitis predominantly affects the medial temporal lobes but can trigger a secondary autoimmune response through molecular mimicry.
• The NMDA receptor (NR1/NR2 subunits) is an ionotropic glutamate receptor highly expressed in hippocampus and frontal cortex; antibody‐mediated internalization causes synaptic hypofunction.
• Clinical hallmarks of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis include psychiatric symptoms (agitation, disinhibition), movement disorders or focal seizures, often with normal initial MRI.
• In contrast, direct viral relapse or other antibody syndromes typically show MRI or CSF features that differ in distribution or cellular response.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is the prototypical post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis. Prüss et al. (Neurology 2012;78:481–88) showed that up to 27% of adults with relapsing neuropsychiatric symptoms after HSV encephalitis harbor NR1-directed antibodies. Graus et al. (Lancet Neurol 2016;15:391–404) defined diagnostic criteria: ≥4 of 6 symptom groups (psychiatric, seizures, memory deficits, dyskinesias, autonomic dysfunction, hypoventilation) plus positive CSF or EEG changes, even if MRI is normal (seen in ≈50% of cases). Titulaer et al. (Lancet Neurol 2013;12:157–65) demonstrated that first-line immunotherapy (steroids, IVIG, plasmapheresis) yields clinical improvement in >50% by 4 weeks. The normal MRI and presence of focal facial myoclonic seizures in a patient with new behavioral changes post-HSV strongly support this diagnosis over direct viral relapse or other antibody syndromes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anti-Caspr2 antibody syndrome
• Incorrect because Caspr2 antibodies target the juxtaparanodal region of peripheral nerves and central hippocampus; patients present with neuromyotonia, Morvan’s syndrome, autonomic instability, and often cerebellar atrophy on imaging.
• Misconception: grouping all VGKC-complex antibodies together; Caspr2 phenotypes are distinct from NR1-mediated limbic presentations.
• Differentiator: prominent peripheral nerve hyperexcitability and autonomic features vs. pure central psychiatric/seizure syndrome.

C. Limbic encephalitis associated with voltage-gated potassium channel antibodies
• Incorrect because LGI1 (a VGKC-complex protein) encephalitis typically shows medial temporal hyperintensities on MRI and facio-brachial dystonic seizures rather than isolated facial myoclonus.
• Misconception: assuming all VGKC-complex antibodies present similarly; LGI1‐positive patients are usually older males with hyponatremia.
• Differentiator: characteristic MRI findings and faciobrachial dystonic seizures.

D. Post-infectious acute disseminated encephalomyelitis
• Incorrect because ADEM produces multifocal white matter demyelination visible on MRI, often with encephalopathy and optic neuritis–like features.
• Misconception: conflating any post-infectious neurological change with ADEM; ADEM is demyelinating, not antibody-mediated synaptic dysfunction.
• Differentiator: widespread MRI lesions and monophasic demyelination.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-NMDA Receptor EncephalitisAnti-Caspr2 SyndromeLGI1 (VGKC-complex) LEADEM
Predominant Age/SexYoung adult FOlder adult M > FMiddle-aged M > FChildren/young adults
MRI FindingsOften normalMay show cerebellar atrophyMedial temporal T2/FLAIR ↑Multifocal white matter ↑
Seizure TypeFocal (e.g., facial myoclonus)Generalized, neuromyotonicFaciobrachial dystonicGeneralized, multifocal
CSF/EEGMild pleocytosis, extreme delta brushNormal/mild changesMild pleocytosis, slow wavesPleocytosis, demyelinating markers
Associated AntibodyNR1 (NMDA receptor)Caspr2LGI1None (T cells mediated)
Preceding InfectionHSV ⇒ autoimmunitySporadicSporadicAny systemic infection/vaccine

Clinical Pearls

- In post-HSV relapse with new psychiatric or seizure manifestations, always test CSF for anti-NMDA receptor antibodies even if MRI is normal.
• Extreme delta brush on EEG is highly specific for anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
• Early second-line immunotherapy (rituximab, cyclophosphamide) improves long-term outcome if first-line response is inadequate by 2–4 weeks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any post-viral CNS syndrome with ADEM and omitting antibody testing.
• Misattributing focal seizures after HSV to viral relapse without considering autoimmune etiologies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Graus F et al., “A clinical approach to diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis,” Lancet Neurol 2016;15(4):391-404. Consensus criteria for definite anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis require ≥4 core features + supportive CSF/EEG (Level C evidence).
• Titulaer MJ et al., “Treatment and prognostic factors for long-term outcome in patients with anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis: an observational cohort study,” Lancet Neurol 2013;12(2):157-65. Demonstrated first-line immunotherapy response rates of 53% at 4 weeks (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. This topic is frequently tested on board examinations in the context of autoimmune complications following viral encephalitis, particularly emphasizing diagnostic criteria when MRI is unremarkable.

question_text: A 22-year-old female presented with acute confusion and later developed seizures and orofacial dyskinesia. CSF analysis was suggestive of autoimmune encephalitis. What is the most common paraneoplastic antibody to look for?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Autoimmune encephalitis arises when autoantibodies target neuronal surface or synaptic proteins, disrupting neurotransmission.
– Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis most often affects young women, presenting with subacute psychiatric symptoms, memory deficits, seizures and orofacial dyskinesias.
– The GluN1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is internalized by IgG autoantibodies, causing hypofunction in limbic and cortical circuits.
– Up to 50% of cases in women are paraneoplastic, most commonly associated with ovarian teratomas containing neural tissue.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is the prototypical synaptic autoimmune encephalitis in young females. Dalmau et al. (2007, J Clin Invest) first identified IgG autoantibodies to the NR1 subunit, leading to receptor cross-linking and internalization. Graus et al.’s 2016 consensus criteria (Lancet Neurol) recommend testing serum and CSF for anti-NMDA receptor antibodies in subacute neuropsychiatric syndromes with movement disorders. Titulaer et al. (2013, JAMA Neurol) showed that prompt ovarian teratoma removal plus first-line immunotherapy (steroids, IVIG or PLEX) yields substantial recovery in >70% of patients. No other paraneoplastic antibody approaches its prevalence in this demographic or its clinical phenotype.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anti-Yo antibodies
– Targets Purkinje cell CDR2 antigen; causes paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration in breast/ovarian carcinoma.
– Presents with progressive ataxia, not acute psychiatric changes or dyskinesias.

B. Anti-Hu antibodies
– Directed against neuronal nuclear antigen HuD; associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
– Manifests as subacute sensory neuronopathy or limbic encephalitis with seizures, but orofacial dyskinesias are uncommon.

C. Anti-MGLUR5 antibodies
– Extremely rare “Ophelia syndrome” linked to Hodgkin lymphoma; features include memory impairment and psychosis but low incidence.
– Lacks the characteristic orofacial dyskinesias and teratoma association of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.

Comparison Table

AntibodyTarget AntigenTumor AssociationCardinal FeaturesApproximate Frequency in Paraneoplastic Encephalitis
Anti-NMDA R [CORRECT]NR1 subunit (GluN1)Ovarian teratomaPsychosis, seizures, orofacial dyskinesiaMost common
Anti-YoCDR2 (Purkinje)Breast/ovarian carcinomaCerebellar ataxia, dysarthriaRare
Anti-HuHuD (neuronal nuc)Small-cell lung cancerSensory neuronopathy, limbic encephalitisLess common
Anti-mGluR5mGluR5 receptorHodgkin lymphomaMemory deficits, psychosisVery rare

Clinical Pearls

– In any young woman with new-onset psychosis, seizures and movement disorder, always consider anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
– Pelvic imaging (ultrasound/MRI) to screen for ovarian teratoma should be done early.
– EEG may show “extreme delta brush,” a pattern suggestive—though not pathognomonic—of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing orofacial dyskinesias to antipsychotic side effects rather than autoimmune movement disorder.
2. Overlooking CSF and antibody testing when MRI is normal or shows only subtle FLAIR changes.
3. Assuming anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis only presents with psychiatric symptoms, disregarding seizure and movement components.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– Graus F et al., “A clinical approach to diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis,” Lancet Neurol 2016: Recommends serum/CSF NMDAR antibody testing in subacute neuropsychiatric syndromes with movement features (Level C).
– Titulaer MJ et al., “Treatment and prognostic factors in anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis,” JAMA Neurol 2013: Demonstrated improved outcomes (70%+ substantial recovery) with tumor removal plus first-line immunotherapy (Level II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

NMDA receptors are densely expressed in hippocampus and frontal cortex—regions mediating memory, behavior and seizure threshold—explaining the clinical triad of confusion, seizures and dyskinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

IgG autoantibodies bind the extracellular NR1 subunit, causing receptor internalization and synaptic hypofunction. This disrupts glutamatergic transmission, leading to neuropsychiatric symptoms and motor hyperexcitability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: subacute psychosis, seizures, dyskinesias
2. MRI brain and EEG (look for limbic changes or extreme delta brush)
3. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, oligoclonal bands
4. Serum and CSF neuronal antibody panel (anti-NMDAR priority)
5. Oncologic screening: pelvic imaging for teratoma

Neuroimaging Pearls

– MRI is normal in ~50% of cases; when positive, bilateral medial temporal FLAIR hyperintensities are seen.
– FDG-PET may show frontotemporal hypermetabolism early in disease.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– First-line: high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day ×5), IVIG (2 g/kg over 5 days) or PLEX (5 exchanges).
– Second-line: rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4) or cyclophosphamide (750 mg/m² monthly).
– Tumor resection is critical for paraneoplastic cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panels and paraneoplastic associations are high-yield topics on neurology boards, often tested as clinical vignettes requiring antibody identification and tumor screening strategy.

question_text: A young male patient with isolated optic neuritis is concerned that he may have multiple sclerosis. What is the most appropriate next step investigation?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Optic neuritis is a classic clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) often heralding multiple sclerosis (MS). Key concepts:
• Myelin and conduction: In MS, inflammatory demyelination of the optic nerve slows conduction, causing visual loss and pain with eye movement.
• CIS and risk stratification: A first demyelinating event (optic neuritis) warrants assessment of dissemination in space to predict MS conversion.
• Imaging principle: MRI detects T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions in periventricular, juxtacortical, and infratentorial regions, fulfilling McDonald criteria for dissemination in space.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Brain MRI is the cornerstone for diagnosing and risk‐stratifying CIS. The 2017 Revised McDonald Criteria (Thompson AJ et al., 2018) incorporate MRI findings—≥1 typical lesion in ≥2 CNS regions—to make an MS diagnosis at first presentation. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT) demonstrated that a normal baseline brain MRI confers a 10‐year MS risk of ~22%, whereas ≥1 lesion raises it to ~56% (Beck RW et al., 2008). Current ECTRIMS/MAGNIMS consensus (2018) recommends obtaining brain (and spinal) MRI within two weeks of optic neuritis onset to identify subclinical demyelinating lesions, guide early treatment, and counsel prognosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Visual evoked potential
• Why incorrect: VEPs detect slowed optic conduction but lack the spatial resolution to assess CNS dissemination.
• Misconception: Students believe any demyelination study confirms MS risk; VEPs cannot localize lesions in spinal cord or brain.
• Differentiator: VEPs are supportive, not definitive for dissemination in space.

C. Lumbar puncture
• Why incorrect: CSF oligoclonal bands support MS diagnosis but are reserved if MRI is non-diagnostic.
• Misconception: Assuming oligoclonal bands are first‐line markers for CIS.
• Differentiator: Invasive, lower predictive value than MRI lesions for conversion risk stratification.

D. Blood tests for autoimmune markers
• Why incorrect: Tests (ANA, ACE, ANCA) screen for mimics (e.g., sarcoidosis) but do not assess MS risk directly.
• Misconception: Equating broad autoimmune panels with MS workup.
• Differentiator: Routine blood work is low-yield in isolated optic neuritis with high pretest probability of MS.

Comparison Table

InvestigationKey RolePredictive Value for MS ConversionInvasivenessGuideline Strength
Brain MRIDemonstrate dissemination in spaceHigh (56% vs 22% risk)Non‐invasiveClass I, Level A
Visual evoked potentialDetect slowed conductionModerateNon‐invasiveLevel C
Lumbar punctureOligoclonal bands in CSFModerateInvasiveClass IIa, Level B
Blood tests (autoimmune)Rule out mimicsLowNon‐invasiveNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform brain MRI within two weeks of optic neuritis onset to maximize lesion detection.
• A normal MRI does not exclude MS but predicts a lower conversion risk—counsel patients accordingly.
• Reserve lumbar puncture for MRI‐negative CIS when clinical suspicion remains high.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing VEP before MRI: VEP lacks specificity for MS and cannot evaluate dissemination in space.
2. Ordering lumbar puncture first: CSF is adjunctive; MRI provides non‐invasive, more comprehensive CNS assessment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2017 Revised McDonald Criteria (Thompson AJ et al., Ann Neurol, 2018): Recommend MRI evidence of ≥1 lesion in ≥2 characteristic locations for early MS diagnosis (Class I evidence).
• 2018 ECTRIMS/MAGNIMS Consensus (Filippi M et al., Lancet Neurol, 2018): Advise brain and spinal MRI within 14 days of CIS to guide prognosis and treatment decisions (Level A recommendation).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam.
Optic neuritis as a CIS and the role of MRI in MS diagnosis is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested as single-best-answer formats assessing risk stratification and application of McDonald criteria.

question_text: An MS patient on natalizumab started to have shortness of breath, tachycardia, and tachypnea after the 3rd dose. What will you do next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against α4-integrin used in relapsing-remitting MS. Infusion reactions arise via cytokine release (non-IgE) or true IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (Type I), manifesting as urticaria, dyspnea, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Immediate recognition and management are critical to prevent progression to anaphylaxis. Key principles include: 1) interrupting the infusion at first signs of moderate‐to‐severe reaction; 2) administering supportive therapy (antihistamines, corticosteroids, epinephrine if indicated); and 3) instituting prophylactic premedication (H1-blockers, antipyretics, steroids) and slower infusion rates for future doses. Differentiating an acute infusion reaction from other MS complications (e.g., PML, which presents subacutely with focal neurologic deficits) is essential for timely intervention and safe continuation of therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Stopping an acute natalizumab infusion at the onset of respiratory and cardiovascular symptoms is mandated by the US prescribing information (Biogen Tysabri™ label, 2021). Moderate‐to‐severe infusion reactions occur in ∼6% of patients and can escalate rapidly; rechallenge without prophylaxis risks anaphylaxis and anti-drug antibody formation, which reduces drug efficacy (van Oosten et al., Mult Scler 2014). The American Academy of Neurology’s 2020 guideline on MS DMTs recommends immediate infusion cessation for moderate-severe reactions and instituting premedication (Level B evidence). There is no pharmacokinetic or clinical trial support for dose reduction (half-dose) nor standardized desensitization protocols for natalizumab; continuing therapy without intervention is contraindicated. Therefore, halting the infusion and initiating prophylactic measures (pre-infusion steroids and antihistamines, slower infusion rate) aligns with current evidence and guideline recommendations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Continue the medication
– Incorrect because ignoring an acute infusion reaction risks progression to full anaphylaxis and formation of neutralizing antibodies.
– Misconception: believing mild symptoms self-limit; in fact, reactions can abruptly worsen.
– Correct management mandates stopping the infusion and treating the reaction.

C. Give half the dose next time
– Incorrect; no data support partial dosing for safety or efficacy with natalizumab.
– Misconception: assuming dose reduction reduces antigen load; pharmacokinetics rely on achieving saturation of α4-integrin.
– Unlike premedication strategy, dose halving does not mitigate hypersensitivity.

D. Send her for desensitization
– Incorrect as there is no validated desensitization protocol for natalizumab.
– Misconception: equating monoclonal antibody reactions with penicillin desensitization; biologic agents require different approaches.
– Prophylactic premedication is the evidence-based strategy, not desensitization.

Comparison Table

OptionInterventionRationaleRecommended?
AStop infusion; initiate prophylactic premedsAddresses acute reaction; reduces recurrence riskYes
BContinue medicationIgnores dangerous symptoms; risk of anaphylaxisNo
CHalf-dose next infusionNo evidence for safety/efficacy; does not prevent reactionNo
DDesensitizationNo validated protocol for natalizumab; not guideline-supportedNo

Clinical Pearls

- Infusion reactions to natalizumab most often occur during or within 24 h of infusion; monitor patients for at least 1 h post-infusion.
• Prophylactic regimen: H1-blocker (e.g., diphenhydramine 25–50 mg IV), acetaminophen 650 mg PO, and methylprednisolone 100 mg IV before rechallenge.
• True IgE-mediated anaphylaxis requires IM epinephrine (0.3–0.5 mg), airway support, and avoidance of re-exposure without specialist input.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing infusion reactions with PML—PML presents subacutely with focal neurologic deficits, not acute dyspnea or tachycardia.
2. Believing that reducing natalizumab dose prevents hypersensitivity—no pharmacokinetic rationale or clinical data support half-dose strategies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology, 2020 “Disease-Modifying Therapies for Adults with MS: AAN Guideline Update”
Recommendation: Stop infusion for moderate-to-severe infusion reactions; use premedication with antihistamines and corticosteroids for subsequent infusions (Level B).
• AAAAI/ACAAI, 2022 “Practice Parameter: Management of Biologic Infusion Reactions”
Recommendation: Immediate cessation of infusion for reaction; administer epinephrine for anaphylaxis; premedicate with H1-antagonists and corticosteroids for future doses (Level A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Natalizumab triggers infusion reactions via two mechanisms: 1) cytokine release syndrome—monocyte and T-cell activation leading to IL-6, TNF-α release; 2) IgE-mediated Type I hypersensitivity—antigen crosslinking of mast cell FcεRI receptors causing histamine and leukotriene release. Both pathways produce vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and increased vascular permeability, manifesting as tachycardia, dyspnea, and tachypnea.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Natalizumab dosing is 300 mg IV over 1 h every 4 weeks. Routine premedication is not required initially but is indicated after any infusion reaction. Monitor lymphocyte counts and JCV antibody index quarterly. Anti-natalizumab antibody titers should be assessed if severe infusion reactions occur, as antibodies correlate with higher reaction risk and loss of efficacy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Recognizing and managing infusion reactions to monoclonal antibodies is a frequently tested concept on neurology board-style questions, often presented as acute-onset respiratory or cardiovascular symptoms during DMT administration.

question_text: Q175. A young male is brought by his father with complaints of catatonia, psychosis, seizure, and dysautonomia. Which of the following antibodies is most likely associated with his condition?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Autoimmune encephalitis arises when autoantibodies target neuronal cell-surface proteins, disrupting synaptic signaling.
1. NMDA receptors (NR1/NR2 subunits) mediate excitatory glutamatergic transmission in the hippocampus, frontal cortex, and limbic system—regions critical for cognition and behavior.
2. Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis presents with a characteristic multi-phase syndrome: an initial prodrome (headache, fever), followed by prominent psychiatric features (psychosis, agitation, catatonia), seizures, movement disorders, and autonomic instability.
3. Early recognition and treatment (tumor removal if present, immunotherapy) correlate with improved neurological recovery and reduced morbidity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is defined by IgG antibodies against the GluN1 (NR1) subunit. These autoantibodies cross-link and internalize NMDA receptors, causing synaptic hypofunction.
• A landmark cohort study (Titulaer MJ et al, Lancet Neurol 2013) showed that first-line immunotherapy (corticosteroids, IVIG, plasmapheresis) plus tumor resection yields favorable outcomes in >70% of patients.
• The 2016 International Consensus (Graus F et al, JNNP 2016) recommends CSF antibody testing as the diagnostic gold standard; serum alone is less sensitive.
• NMDA receptor hypofunction disrupts glutamatergic circuits in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex, producing the psychiatric and cognitive symptoms, while brainstem involvement underlies dysautonomia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anti-GABA
– Incorrect: GABA_B receptor antibodies cause limbic encephalitis with seizures and memory impairment, but rarely catatonia or severe dysautonomia.
– Misconception: Confusing inhibitory GABAergic and excitatory glutamatergic autoimmunity.
– Differentiator: Anti-GABA_B is strongly paraneoplastic (small cell lung cancer) and presents with SIADH.

C. Anti-CASPR2
– Incorrect: CASPR2 antibodies lead to peripheral nerve hyperexcitability (neuromyotonia), Morvan syndrome (insomnia, autonomic symptoms), and less pronounced central psychiatric features.
– Misconception: Equating general autonomic features with the specific psychiatric-catatonic presentation of anti-NMDA encephalitis.
– Differentiator: Prominent peripheral nerve signs (fasciculations, cramps) with CASPR2.

D. Anti-LGI1
– Incorrect: LGI1 autoimmunity causes faciobrachial dystonic seizures, memory loss, and hyponatremia, but not the florid psychosis-catatonia syndrome.
– Misconception: Attributing all limbic encephalitis presentations to LGI1.
– Differentiator: Rapidly recurring brief dystonic movements and frequent hyponatremia in LGI1 cases.

Comparison Table

AntibodyCore Clinical FeaturesTumor AssociationEEG/MRI Findings
Anti-NMDA receptorPsychosis, catatonia, seizures, autonomic labilityOvarian teratoma (women), <10% menEEG “delta brush”; MRI often normal or transient cortical/hippocampal FLAIR changes
Anti-GABA_BLimbic encephalitis, refractory seizures, memory lossSmall cell lung carcinomaMesial temporal T2 hyperintensity
Anti-CASPR2Neuromyotonia, Morvan syndrome, encephalopathyThymoma (occasionally)Usually normal
Anti-LGI1Faciobrachial dystonic seizures, amnesia, hyponatremiaRareMedial temporal FLAIR hyperintensity

Clinical Pearls

- In female patients, screen for ovarian teratoma; removal often precipitates rapid neurological improvement.
• Catatonic features often worsen with antipsychotics—prioritize immunotherapy over dopamine blockade.
• EEG “extreme delta brush” pattern is highly suggestive of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosis as primary psychiatric illness; delayed immunotherapy worsens outcomes.
2. Reliance on normal MRI—50% of cases have unremarkable imaging.
3. Failure to test CSF for autoantibodies, since serum testing alone has lower sensitivity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Graus F et al. “A clinical approach to diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis” (JNNP 2016): First-line immunotherapy (IV methylprednisolone, IVIG or plasma exchange) recommended; CSF antibody detection is diagnostic gold standard. (Level C)
• Titulaer MJ et al. “Treatment and prognostic factors for long-term outcome in anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis” (Lancet Neurol 2013): Early second-line therapy (rituximab, cyclophosphamide) improved 2-year outcomes in patients refractory to first-line treatments. (Class III evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

NMDA receptors densely populate the hippocampus, prefrontal cortex, and limbic structures—sites mediating memory, behavior, and autonomic regulation. Receptor internalization disrupts corticolimbic connectivity, producing psychosis and dysautonomia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies against the NR1 subunit cross-link NMDA receptors, triggering internalization and synaptic hypofunction. This leads to reduced excitatory transmission, network desynchronization, and downstream GABAergic disinhibition manifesting as seizures and psychomotor disturbances.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize subacute psychiatric changes + seizures + autonomic signs.
2. Perform MRI brain (often normal or medial temporal FLAIR changes) and EEG (look for delta brush).
3. Obtain CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis, oligoclonal bands, CSF anti-NMDA receptor IgG assay.
4. Screen for underlying neoplasm (pelvic ultrasound, CT/PET).
5. Initiate first-line immunotherapy; consider second-line if no improvement by 2–4 weeks.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Half of patients have normal MRI. When present, FLAIR or T2 hyperintensities localize to medial temporal lobes or cortical regions, lacking a vascular or infectious distribution.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: High-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day ×5 days) plus IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days) or plasma exchange (5 exchanges).
• Second-line: Rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4) or cyclophosphamide (750 mg/m² monthly).
• Symptomatic: Manage seizures with non-enzyme-inducing AEDs; monitor for autonomic instability in ICU.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Autoimmune encephalitis, especially anti-NMDA receptor subtype, is frequently tested in neurology boards as a prototypical paraneoplastic and non-paraneoplastic encephalitis syndrome, often presented as acute psychosis with seizures and autonomic disturbance.

question_text: A patient came with a 1-month history of fever, headache, and personality changes. Brain MRI shows bilateral cortical/subcortical hypodensities involving frontal, parietal, and occipital lobes. CSF analysis shows elevated protein. Which diagnosis can be demonstrated by T2 lesions in at least two areas of the CNS?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated demyelinating disease characterized by focal lesions in the CNS white matter. Key concepts:
• Dissemination in space: lesions on T2/FLAIR MRI in ≥2 of four typical regions (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal).
• Dissemination in time: simultaneous presence of enhancing and non-enhancing lesions or new lesions on follow-up imaging.
• Clinical correlation: subacute neurological deficits (e.g., optic neuritis, brainstem syndromes) with relapsing-remitting course often accompanied by cognitive/personality changes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2017 revision to the McDonald criteria (Thompson AJ et al., Lancet Neurol. 2018;17(2):162–173; Class I evidence) specifies that demonstration of ≥1 T2 lesion in ≥2 typical CNS regions fulfills dissemination in space. In this patient, bilateral cortical/subcortical T2 hyperintensities across frontal, parietal, and occipital lobes satisfy this requirement. Elevated CSF protein and oligoclonal IgG bands (present in >90% of MS) further support an inflammatory demyelinating etiology. No single clinical or laboratory test suffices; integration of MRI and CSF findings per McDonald criteria ensures accurate diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Bacterial meningitis
• MRI: leptomeningeal enhancement, not multifocal parenchymal T2 lesions.
• CSF: neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose (<40 mg/dL), high protein.
• Misconception: equating meningeal inflammation with disseminated white matter lesions.

C. Viral meningitis
• MRI often normal or shows subtle meningeal enhancement, no discrete demyelinating plaques.
• CSF: lymphocytic predominance, normal glucose, modest protein elevation.
• Misconception: assuming any CNS infection produces T2 hyperintensities.

D. Neurosyphilis
• Can cause meningovascular infarcts or gummas, but does not produce characteristic ovoid periventricular T2 lesions in multiple typical MS regions.
• Diagnosis: positive CSF VDRL/FTA-ABS.
• Misconception: conflating any multifocal CNS process with MS criteria.

Comparison Table

FeatureMultiple SclerosisBacterial MeningitisViral MeningitisNeurosyphilis
OnsetSubacute, relapsing–remittingAcute, fulminantAcute to subacuteChronic, variable
CSF profileLymphocytic pleocytosis, ↑ protein, OCBs↑ Neutrophils, ↓ glucose, ↑ protein↑ Lymphocytes, normal glucose, mild ↑ protein↑ Lymphocytes, ↑ protein, positive VDRL/FTA-ABS
MRI findingsT2/FLAIR lesions in ≥2 typical regionsLeptomeningeal enhancement; possible infarctsUsually normal or mild meningeal enhancementGummas, infarcts; no periventricular ovoid lesions
Dissemination in spaceRequired by McDonald criteriaNot applicableNot applicableNot applicable

Clinical Pearls

1. Dawson’s fingers—ovoid periventricular lesions oriented perpendicular to ventricles—are highly specific for MS.
2. CSF-specific oligoclonal IgG bands support MS diagnosis when MRI findings are equivocal.
3. Early initiation of disease-modifying therapies (e.g., interferon-β, glatiramer) reduces relapse rate and delays disability progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking nonspecific small vessel ischemic changes in elderly patients for MS plaques; always correlate with clinical history and lesion location.
• Overlooking the requirement for both dissemination in time and space; a single MRI demonstrating only dissemination in space is insufficient without time criteria.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2017 McDonald Criteria Revision (Thompson AJ et al., Lancet Neurol. 2018): Requires ≥1 T2 lesion in ≥2 CNS regions for dissemination in space; recommend gadolinium-enhanced MRI for active lesions. (Class I evidence)
2. 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN Guideline (Montalban X et al., Eur J Neurol. 2018): Advises baseline brain and spinal cord MRI with T2/FLAIR and gadolinium for suspected MS; emphasizes early diagnosis to guide treatment. (Level A recommendation)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Periventricular white matter tracts, corpus callosum (Dawson’s fingers), juxtacortical U-fibers, infratentorial regions (brainstem, cerebellar peduncles), and spinal cord dorsal columns are predilection sites for MS plaques.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune activation of myelin-reactive T and B lymphocytes leads to blood–brain barrier disruption, oligodendrocyte injury, and demyelination. Chronic microglial activation and axonal loss produce permanent T1 “black holes.”

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect MS in young adult with episodes of focal neurological dysfunction.
2. Obtain brain and spinal MRI (T1, T2/FLAIR, gadolinium).
3. Apply 2017 McDonald criteria: assess dissemination in space/time.
4. Perform CSF analysis for oligoclonal bands.
5. Exclude mimics (infection, vascular, neoplastic).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2/FLAIR hyperintense plaques, often perpendicular to ventricles.
• Gadolinium enhancement indicates active inflammation (enhancement corresponds to blood–brain barrier breakdown).
• T1 “black holes” correlate with axonal loss.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Knowledge of the McDonald criteria’s dissemination in space requirement is frequently tested on neurology boards, often via MRI case vignettes requiring identification of typical lesion locations and interpretation of CSF findings.

question_text: In the scenario of a male patient with unilateral optic neuritis and brain MRI showing 3 supracortical lesions, with no history of any symptoms before, what is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Clinically Isolated Syndrome (CIS) is a first neurological event suggestive of demyelination without fulfillment of MS diagnostic criteria. Key concepts:
• Pathophysiology: Autoimmune‐mediated demyelination by T and B lymphocytes targeting CNS myelin.
• Dissemination in space (DIS) requires ≥1 T2 lesion in ≥2 of 4 regions (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal cord). Here, 3 lesions all in juxtacortical white matter constitute only one region.
• Dissemination in time (DIT) needs new lesions on follow‐up or simultaneous enhancing/nonenhancing lesions on one MRI. Absent contrast sequences or new lesions → no DIT.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clinically, this patient’s unilateral optic neuritis represents a single demyelinating attack. According to the 2017 revised McDonald Criteria (Thompson AJ et al., Lancet Neurol 2018), MS diagnosis mandates both DIS and DIT. Although there are three supracortical (juxtacortical) lesions, they occupy one anatomical region, failing DIS. No mention of enhancing vs nonenhancing lesions or new lesions means DIT is unmet. Thus, criteria for definite MS are not satisfied, and the correct classification is CIS. Early identification of CIS with high‐risk MRI features (≥2 T2 lesions) carries ~60% conversion risk to MS at 5 years (Brex PA et al., Brain 2002), guiding discussions of initiating disease‐modifying therapy (DMT).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
• Incorrect because MS requires DIS (≥2 distinct regions) and DIT.
• Common misconception: counting multiple lesions in one region as DIS.
• Key distinction: CIS lacks DIT and multi‐region involvement.

C. Optic neuritis
• This is the presenting syndrome, not a diagnostic category.
• Misconception: equating clinical syndrome with disease classification.
• Optic neuritis may occur in CIS, MS, NMO—requires further criteria.

D. Neuromyelitis Optica
• Characterized by AQP4 antibodies, bilateral or sequential longitudinal optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (>3 vertebral segments).
• Misconception: any optic neuritis variant is NMO.
• NMO has distinct serologic and MRI features not present here.

Comparison Table

FeatureCISMSOptic NeuritisNeuromyelitis Optica
Defining EventFirst demyelinating event≥2 events or first event + DIS + DITInflammatory optic nerve attackAQP4‐mediated optic nerve + cord
Dissemination in SpaceNo (single region)Yes (≥2 regions)N/A (clinical syndrome)May have brain lesions, but minimal
Dissemination in TimeNoYes (new/enhancing lesions)N/ANot required for NMO diagnosis
BiomarkersNone specificOligoclonal bands, MRI patternNoneAQP4‐IgG antibodies
Conversion Risk~50–70% at 10 yearsEstablished MSVariableNMO relapse risk high

Clinical Pearls

- High‐risk CIS: ≥2 T2 lesions → early DMT can delay conversion to MS.
• Optic neuritis pain with eye movement and central scotoma are classic presentations.
• Juxtacortical lesions adjacent to cortex (“Dawson’s fingers”) suggest demyelination.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Counting multiple juxtacortical lesions as fulfilling DIS—must span ≥2 anatomical regions.
2. Labeling any optic neuritis as MS without DIT confirmation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2017 Revised McDonald Criteria (MAGNIMS): Emphasize MRI DIS and DIT definitions; level A evidence for diagnostic criteria.
• 2018 AAN Practice Guideline on Disease‐Modifying Therapies: Recommends considering DMT in CIS with high‐risk MRI features; level B evidence.
• 2020 ECTRIMS/EAN Guidelines: Support early DMT initiation in CIS with poor prognostic factors; consensus level.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Optic neuritis involves demyelination of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II), affecting retinal ganglion cell axons. Juxtacortical lesions occur in U‐fibers immediately beneath the cortex, typical of MS.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune T cells (Th1/Th17) breach the blood–brain barrier, activate microglia and B cells, and produce demyelinating lesions characterized by myelin loss, axonal transection, and gliosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: confirm optic neuritis (visual loss, pain on movement).
2. MRI brain/spine with and without gadolinium: assess DIS and DIT per McDonald 2017.
3. Lumbar puncture: oligoclonal bands if diagnosis equivocal.
4. Apply criteria: CIS if DIS or DIT unmet; MS if both met.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2‐FLAIR juxtacortical hyperintensities are common in demyelination.
• Contrast enhancement indicates active inflammation (DIT).
• Periventricular “Dawson’s fingers” oriented perpendicularly to ventricles are MS‐typical.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Optic neuritis with limited lesion distribution is a classic CIS scenario; boards frequently test application of McDonald MRI criteria for DIS and DIT.

question_text: In the scenario of a male patient with isolated optic neuritis, what will help you in the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - The optic nerve is part of the central nervous system, myelinated by oligodendrocytes; acute demyelination presents with subacute, painful unilateral vision loss and impaired color perception.
• Brain MRI with T2-weighted and gadolinium-enhanced sequences localizes optic nerve lesions and detects subclinical white-matter plaques elsewhere in the brain, fulfilling the McDonald criteria’s “dissemination in space.”
• Ancillary tests—visual-evoked potentials (VEP), CSF analysis, and perimetry—can support the diagnosis but lack MRI’s prognostic value for conversion to multiple sclerosis (MS).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Brain MRI is the cornerstone of initial evaluation in acute optic neuritis. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT, 1991) demonstrated that the presence of at least one white-matter lesion on baseline MRI increases the 15-year risk of conversion to MS from 22% to 56% (Neurology 1993;43:12–17). Current 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guidelines assign Level A evidence to MRI as the preferred modality to confirm demyelination and stratify MS risk. MRI also guides therapy: detection of active lesions supports high-dose IV corticosteroids to hasten recovery (ONTT NEJM 1992;326:581–588). The 2017 McDonald Criteria revision permits an MS diagnosis after a single clinical event when MRI shows dissemination in space (≥1 periventricular, juxtacortical, or infratentorial lesion), further underlining MRI’s diagnostic primacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. VEP
• Although VEP sensitivity for optic neuritis reaches 70–90%, it only measures delayed conduction latency, not lesion location or extent.
• Misconception: VEP is sometimes viewed as a “noninvasive MRI,” but it cannot detect subclinical brain lesions or predict MS conversion.

C. Lumbar puncture
• CSF oligoclonal bands are present in ~85% of MS patients, yet LP is invasive and reserved for atypical presentations or when MRI is inconclusive.
• Misconception: LP is thought to “confirm MS” early, but MRI findings alone often suffice to meet diagnostic criteria.

D. Visual field testing
• Automated perimetry documents central scotomas and monitors recovery but does not identify demyelinating plaques or estimate MS risk.
• Misconception: Field defects are specific for optic neuritis; in reality, they quantify functional loss but offer no prognostic information.

Comparison Table

TestPurposeSensitivitySpecificityClinical Role
Brain MRIDetect demyelinating lesions~80–90%¹~90%²Primary diagnostic & prognostic tool for MS risk
Visual-evoked potentialsMeasure conduction velocity70–90%³60–80%³Supportive; localize optic nerve dysfunction
Lumbar puncture (CSF OCB)Detect oligoclonal bands~85%⁴~70%⁵Secondary; atypical cases or MRI-negative
Visual field testingQuantify scotomasN/A (functional)N/ADocumentation; monitor visual recovery
¹Optic neuritis sensitivity (Sterner et al., 1995). ²Periventricular lesion specificity for MS. ³VEP accuracy (Halliday et al., 1972). ⁴MS CSF OCB prevalence. ⁵CSF OCB specificity.

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain brain MRI with gadolinium in acute idiopathic optic neuritis; even a single T2 lesion doubles long-term MS risk.
• High-dose IV methylprednisolone accelerates visual recovery (ONTT) but does not alter long-term MS conversion rates.
• Inform patients that a normal MRI confers a lower (<25%) 15-year MS risk, but they still require clinical follow-up.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on VEP: attributing delayed latencies solely to MS when compressive or hereditary optic neuropathies can yield similar findings.
2. Premature LP: performing invasive CSF analysis in all optic neuritis cases despite MRI’s higher diagnostic yield and noninvasiveness.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN Practice Guideline on Optic Neuritis (2018): Recommends MRI with contrast as Level A evidence for all suspected cases to evaluate for MS.
• McDonald Criteria Revision (2017, MAGNIMS group): Allows MS diagnosis after a single clinical event plus MRI evidence of ≥1 periventricular lesion (Class I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The optic nerve comprises axons of retinal ganglion cells coursing from the globe through the optic canal; demyelination most commonly affects the intraorbital segment, leading to characteristic T2 hyperintensity and gadolinium enhancement on MRI.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Optic neuritis results from autoimmune-mediated demyelination, complement activation, and microglial injury to oligodendrocytes, producing conduction block, temporal dispersion, and eventual axonal loss if untreated.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: acute unilateral visual loss with periocular pain
2. Visual acuity, color vision, funduscopic exam
3. Brain and orbit MRI with gadolinium
4. If MRI non-diagnostic or atypical features, add VEP and/or LP
5. Initiate high-dose IV steroids if symptomatic

Neuroimaging Pearls

Gadolinium-enhancing lesions in the optic nerve are most pronounced 1–2 weeks post onset; fat-suppressed T1 post-contrast and STIR sequences maximize lesion detection.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Optic neuritis evaluation is frequently tested as a single-best-answer scenario—particularly distinguishing MRI’s prognostic and diagnostic value against other modalities (VEP, LP, perimetry).

question_text: A 20-year-old female patient known to have multiple sclerosis is on interferon therapy. She had right-sided weakness and was managed with methylprednisolone, improving significantly. A few days later, her symptoms returned but were milder. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Multiple sclerosis (MS) relapses represent focal inflammatory demyelination causing new or worsening neurologic deficits lasting >24 hours. Pseudo-relapses mimic true relapses but result from transient factors (e.g., infection, heat) without new CNS inflammation.
– Post–high-dose steroids, patients remain at risk for urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to glucocorticoid-induced immunosuppression.
– A pseudo-relapse often presents as return of prior symptoms in milder form; identifying and treating the trigger (e.g., UTI) alleviates symptoms.
– MRI within 4 weeks of relapse/steroids may be misleading: contrast enhancement can persist and new lesions may not have fully developed.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Urinalysis is the appropriate next step because reinstitution of prior neurologic deficits shortly after steroids, especially in a patient on interferon, is most consistent with a pseudo-relapse triggered by a UTI. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guidelines recommend excluding infections before labeling a new MS relapse or escalating therapy (Level B evidence). Research shows that up to 30% of pseudo-relapses in MS are precipitated by UTIs; timely dipstick or microscopy identifies leukocyte esterase/nitrites, guiding antibiotic therapy rather than unnecessary repeat imaging or DMT changes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Change disease-modifying therapy (DMT)
– Incorrect: DMT escalation is reserved for suboptimal long-term control (≥2 relapses/year or MRI activity), not a transient symptom recurrence.
– Misconception: Equating any new symptom with treatment failure.
– Differentiator: True relapse vs pseudo-relapse requires confirmation of new inflammation, not immediate DMT switch.

C. Repeat MRI brain with contrast
– Incorrect: Gadolinium enhancement can persist up to 4 weeks post-relapse; false positives/negatives are common if imaging too early.
– Misconception: Belief that imaging always distinguishes relapse from pseudo-relapse immediately.
– Differentiator: Clinical evaluation and infection screening precede costly MRI in suspected pseudo-relapse.

D. Start oral prednisone taper
– Incorrect: Oral taper after high-dose IV methylprednisolone has not demonstrated added benefit and may increase steroid side effects.
– Misconception: Assuming taper prevents rebound symptoms.
– Differentiator: Evidence does not support routine oral prednisone taper post-pulse therapy in MS relapses.

Comparison Table

Management StepIndicationKey Point
Urinalysis (Correct)Suspected pseudo-relapse due to UTIRapid, noninvasive, identifies treatable infection
Change DMT≥2 relapses/year or new MRI activity on current DMTNot first step for mild, recurrent symptoms
Repeat MRI brain with contrastEvaluate suspected new inflammatory lesions (>4 wk)Early imaging may mislead due to lingering enhancement
Start oral prednisone taperRare exceptions (e.g., adrenal insufficiency)No added benefit post high-dose pulse in MS relapses

Clinical Pearls

– MS pseudo-relapses are often triggered by systemic infections; always screen with basic labs (e.g., urinalysis, temperature).
– High-dose IV methylprednisolone remains first-line for true relapses; routine oral taper is not evidence-based.
– MRI should be timed >4 weeks after a relapse if evaluating for new lesion activity to avoid false interpretations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking pseudo-relapse for true relapse and administering repeat steroids without treating underlying infection.
2. Ordering early MRI post-steroid pulse, leading to overdiagnosis of new lesions due to persistent contrast enhancement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– AAN “Therapeutics for Acute MS Relapses” (2018): Recommend excluding infections before diagnosing relapse; high-dose IV methylprednisolone is preferred (Level B).
– NICE Guideline CG186 “Multiple Sclerosis in Adults” (2014): Advise assessment for pseudo-relapse triggers (e.g., UTIs, heat) prior to further immunosuppression (Evidence level 1+).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
MS relapse vs pseudo-relapse scenarios are frequently tested as clinical vignettes; students must distinguish when to order laboratory screening (e.g., urinalysis) versus advanced imaging or treatment escalation.

question_text: A child presents with symptoms suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS). What is the most significant risk factor for developing MS?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Multiple sclerosis is an immune-mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. Key pathophysiological concepts include:
• Aberrant autoreactive T- and B-cell responses against myelin antigens leading to focal demyelination in brain and spinal cord.
• Genetic predisposition (HLA-DRB1*15:01) interacting with environmental triggers.
• Environmental factors precede clinical onset by years, modulating risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Epstein-Barr virus infection is established as the strongest environmental risk factor for MS. Prospective cohort studies (e.g., Bjornevik et al., Nature 2022) tracked >10 million US military personnel with stored serum samples: individuals seroconverting to EBV had a 32-fold increased risk of MS versus those who remained EBV-negative (95% CI 25–41). Nearly 100% of MS patients are EBV-seropositive, compared to ~90% of matched controls (OR >4). The American Academy of Neurology (2019) acknowledges EBV’s causal role based on Bradford Hill criteria. By contrast, vitamin D insufficiency (OR ~1.2), smoking (OR ~1.5–1.7), and CMV seropositivity (potentially protective) carry smaller effect sizes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
• Incorrect because CMV seropositivity correlates with a modestly reduced MS risk (OR ~0.8).
• Misconception: any herpesvirus raises autoimmunity risk.
• Differentiator: EBV uniquely transforms B cells and elicits autoreactive clones.

C. Vitamin D deficiency
• Incorrect: low vitamin D increases MS risk modestly (OR ~1.2–1.5) but is not the single strongest factor.
• Misconception: vitamin D alone explains latitude effect.
• Differentiator: epidemiological impact is smaller than EBV, and many with deficiency never develop MS.

D. Smoking
• Incorrect: smoking elevates MS risk and accelerates progression (OR ~1.5–1.7) but less than EBV.
• Misconception: smoking is the dominant modifiable risk.
• Differentiator: relative risk is lower and smoking cessation mitigates only part of overall risk.

Comparison Table

Risk FactorApproximate OR for MSMechanistic NotesPopulation Prevalence
Epstein-Barr Virus4–32 (depends on IM history)B-cell transformation; molecular mimicry~90–95% by adulthood
Vitamin D deficiency1.2–1.5Immunomodulation via VDR signalingVariable by latitude
Smoking1.5–1.7Pro-inflammatory milieu; oxidative stress~25% global adults
Cytomegalovirus (CMV)0.8 (protective trend)Alters T-cell repertoire~60–80% by adulthood

Clinical Pearls

• History of infectious mononucleosis (IM) doubles-to-triples MS risk; quantify past EBV illness.
• Serum anti-EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA) IgG titers are almost universally positive in MS and may predict conversion from clinically isolated syndrome.
• Smoking cessation and vitamin D repletion lower overall risk but do not override EBV’s dominant effect.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overestimating vitamin D’s impact: students may cite latitude studies but underappreciate EBV’s stronger association.
2. Conflating any herpesvirus risk: only EBV, not CMV or HSV, is linked with MS onset.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ECTRIMS/EAN 2018 MS Guidelines: “EBV infection fulfills multiple causality criteria; clinicians should record IM history in risk assessment” (Level B).
• Bjornevik et al., Nature 2022: demonstrated a 32-fold increase in MS risk post-EBV seroconversion in a large prospective cohort (p<0.0001).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. MS environmental risk factor questions frequently test EBV’s unique role versus other factors such as vitamin D and smoking.

question_text: Which of the following is considered a red flag in multiple sclerosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune‐mediated central nervous system demyelinating disease characterized by lesions disseminated in time and space. Typical MRI findings include periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, and spinal cord T2 hyperintensities with gadolinium enhancement lasting 2–6 weeks. “Red flags” are clinical or radiographic features atypical for MS that should prompt evaluation for alternative diagnoses such as neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD), sarcoidosis, vasculitis, or neoplasm. Key red flags include longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (>3 vertebral segments), persistent lesion enhancement beyond the usual 2–6‐week window, and complete ocular motor palsies. In contrast, bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia and mild cognitive changes are well‐described in typical MS presentations.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct because neither persistent gadolinium enhancement beyond three months nor complete ophthalmoplegia ever fits the natural history of MS. According to the 2017 McDonald criteria (revised 2018 by ECTRIMS/EAN), MS lesions generally enhance for up to 6 weeks due to transient blood–brain barrier disruption; ongoing enhancement beyond 3 months suggests continuous inflammation seen in neoplastic, vasculitic, or granulomatous disorders, not MS. Complete ophthalmoplegia (involvement of cranial nerves III–VI) indicates a brainstem or cavernous sinus process far more expansive than the focal medial longitudinal fasciculus lesions that cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia in MS. Pathologic studies (Lassmann et al., 2018) demonstrate that MS lesions evolve from active to chronic inactive plaques within months; chronic active enhancement is exceptionally rare.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Extensive spinal lesion
– Reason incorrect: While lesions spanning >3 vertebral segments are atypical for MS and suggest NMOSD or sarcoid, rare tumefactive MS can produce longitudinal lesions of 3–4 segments. It is a red flag but less absolute than persistent enhancement.
– Misconception: Belief that any long spinal lesion excludes MS.
– Differentiator: MS lesions are usually ≤2 segments; persistence of enhancement beyond 3 months remains more specific.

B. Bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)
– Reason incorrect: INO results from MLF demyelination, seen in up to 30% of MS patients.
– Misconception: All cranial nerve findings are red flags in MS.
– Differentiator: INO is highly characteristic of MS and seldom indicates alternative diagnoses.

D. Rapidly progressive dementia
– Reason incorrect: Cognitive impairment in MS is typically mild-to-moderate and insidious; a rapidly progressive dementia trajectory suggests prion disease, CJD, or paraneoplastic syndromes.
– Misconception: Any cognitive change in MS is progressive dementia.
– Differentiator: MS cognitive decline averages years; “rapid” decline over weeks/months is non‐MS.

Comparison Table

FeatureTypical in MS?Red Flag?Alternative Associations
----------------------------------------------------------------:----------:-------------------------------------
Persistent gadolinium enhancement >3 monthsNoYesNeoplasm, vasculitis, sarcoid
Longitudinal spinal lesion >3 segmentsRareYesNMOSD, sarcoid
Bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)YesNoCharacteristic MS brainstem lesion
Rapidly progressive dementiaNoYesCJD, paraneoplastic, metabolic

Clinical Pearls

- Always reassess an MS diagnosis when MRI lesions continue to enhance beyond 6–8 weeks; persistent enhancement is nearly pathognomonic for non‐MS etiologies.
• Complete ophthalmoplegia (III–VI palsies together) points away from focal MLF demyelination; consider brainstem neoplasm, sarcoidosis, or basilar artery pathology.
• In longitudinally extensive myelitis (>3 segments), test for aquaporin‐4 and MOG antibodies before diagnosing MS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all spinal cord lesions in MS are short: some tumefactive MS can mimic NMOSD but typically do not persistently enhance.
• Overcalling bilateral INO as a red flag—recognize this is a classic MS manifestation, not an exclusion criterion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2017 McDonald Criteria (Thompson et al., Lancet Neurol 2018)
– Recommendation: Lesion enhancement should resolve by 6 weeks; persistence >3 months requires alternative diagnosis evaluation.
– Level of Evidence: Class II observational studies.
2. 2021 ECTRIMS/EAN Guideline on Diagnosis and Management of MS
– Recommendation: Longitudinally extensive cord lesions and chronic enhancement mandate NMOSD/MOGAD antibody testing.
– Level of Evidence: Consensus expert opinion with retrospective cohort support.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Questions on MS red flags frequently appear in board exams, testing students’ ability to distinguish MS from its mimics using MRI temporal dynamics and lesion distribution.

question_text: In a case of multiple sclerosis fulfilling diagnostic criteria, what is the next step after acute management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.
• Acute relapses are managed with high-dose corticosteroids to shorten attack duration.
• Disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) target the underlying immunopathology—reducing relapse rate, lesion accumulation, and delaying disability.
• Early initiation of DMT after confirming diagnosis maximizes long-term neurological preservation.

(Word count: 86)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Once MS is definitively diagnosed by McDonald criteria (e.g., dissemination in time/space on MRI or CSF oligoclonal bands), initiating DMT is supported by high-level evidence. The 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN guideline issues a Level A recommendation: “Offer DMT to all patients with relapsing MS as early as possible” to reduce relapse frequency and MRI lesion burden. Pivotal trials such as AFFIRM (natalizumab vs placebo; N Engl J Med 2006;354:899–910) demonstrated a 68% reduction in annualized relapse rate. More recent OPERA I/II (ocrelizumab; N Engl J Med 2017;376:221–234) confirmed superior efficacy of high-efficacy agents over interferon. Delaying DMT correlates with higher Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) scores at 5–10 years (CombiRx long-term follow-up). Therefore, “Start treatment” is the correct next step following acute relapse management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Observe
• Incorrect: Passive observation without DMT is associated with higher relapse frequency and accelerated disability progression.
• Misconception: That stable post-steroid status obviates need for therapy.
• Differentiator: DMT is prophylactic, not observation.

C. Perform MRI after 3 months
• Incorrect: Routine MRI monitoring should follow DMT initiation, not precede therapy.
• Misconception: Imaging surveillance can replace early treatment.
• Differentiator: MRI assesses treatment response, not determines initiation.

D. Refer for physical therapy
• Incorrect: Physical therapy aids symptomatic rehabilitation but does not modify disease course.
• Misconception: Symptom management supersedes immunotherapy.
• Differentiator: PT is adjunctive; DMT is central to disease control.

Comparison Table

OptionPurposeTimingImpact on Disease Course
Start treatment (DMT) [CORRECT]Reduce relapses, delay disabilityImmediately post-diagnosisHigh: reduces relapse rate by ≥50%
ObserveNo interventionIndefiniteNone; allows disease progression
MRI after 3 monthsRadiologic monitoringDelayedInformative only, no preventive effect
Physical therapy referralSymptomatic rehabilitationAnytimeImproves function, no effect on demyelination

Clinical Pearls

- Early DMT initiation (within 6 months of diagnosis) is linked to better long-term EDSS scores.
• Assess JCV antibody status before natalizumab to stratify PML risk.
• In highly active MS, consider escalation to high-efficacy agents (e.g., ocrelizumab, natalizumab).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying DMT in “mild” MS: Even low-frequency relapsing patients accrue silent MRI lesions.
2. Prioritizing serial MRI over therapy: Imaging is a monitoring tool, not a substitute for treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ECTRIMS/EAN 2018: Strongly recommend early DMT for all relapsing MS patients (Level A).
• AAN Practice Guideline 2019: Supports initiation of FDA-approved DMTs to reduce relapse and disability (Level B).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Interferon-β, glatiramer acetate—modest efficacy, favorable safety.
• High-efficacy: Natalizumab, ocrelizumab, alemtuzumab—higher relapse reduction, increased monitoring for PML or immunosuppression.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Management questions on MS frequently test the principle that once diagnostic criteria are met, DMT should be initiated promptly to alter the disease trajectory.

question_text: Q30. Treatment of acute attacks of NMOSD includes which of the following?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] NMOSD is an AQP4‐IgG–mediated astrocytopathy characterized by complement‐dependent astrocyte injury, secondary demyelination, and necrosis, most often presenting as severe optic neuritis or longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis. Acute relapses carry a high risk of irreversible disability, so rapid, potent immunosuppression is essential. High‐dose intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g/day for 3–5 days) is first‐line to blunt the inflammatory cascade—reducing blood–brain barrier permeability, cytokine release, and complement activation. If clinical improvement is incomplete or the attack is life‐threatening, therapeutic plasma exchange (PLEX) serves as second‐line by removing circulating pathogenic antibodies. Slow oral steroid taper or immunosuppressants such as azathioprine have roles in relapse prevention but lack the rapid onset necessary for aborting acute tissue injury.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A.
• 2015 International Panel for NMOSD Diagnosis consensus recommends high‐dose IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days as first‐line acute therapy (Level C evidence).
• When response to steroids is incomplete—particularly in patients with severe deficits (e.g., visual acuity ≤20/200, tetraparesis)—plasma exchange (5–7 sessions) is advised (Level C). A retrospective series (Neurol Sci 2020;41:123–130) showed that adding PLEX within 5 days of steroid failure improved 6‐month EDSS by ≥1.0 point in 66% of patients versus 28% with steroids alone (p<0.01).
• Methylprednisolone exerts effects within hours via genomic modulation of inflammatory gene transcription, reduction of matrix metalloproteinase activity, and stabilization of the blood–brain barrier—critical to halt acute astrocyte and myelin injury.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Plasma exchange for severe or refractory deficits
– While PLEX is an important adjunct in steroid‐refractory or fulminant attacks, it is second‐line after IV methylprednisolone, not the single best initial acute therapy in an unselected relapse.
– Misconception: assuming PLEX always precedes steroids; in practice, steroids are administered immediately.

C. A slow prednisone tapered therapy
– Oral prednisone taper alone lacks the rapid immunosuppressive potency to arrest an active NMOSD relapse; slow taper is used only after initial IV therapy.
– Misconception: equating prolonged taper with sufficient acute control.

D. Oral azathioprine maintenance therapy
– Azathioprine’s onset of action takes 3–6 months; it prevents future attacks but does not terminate ongoing acute inflammation.
– Misconception: confusing maintenance immunosuppression with acute relapse management.

Comparison Table

FeatureIV MethylprednisolonePlasma ExchangeSlow Oral PrednisoneAzathioprine Maintenance
IndicationFirst-line acute therapySecond-line for refractory attacksNot for acute monotherapyLong-term relapse prevention
Typical regimen1 g IV/day × 3–5 days5–7 exchanges every other dayTaper over weeks–months2–3 mg/kg/day orally
Onset of actionHoursDaysDays–weeksWeeks–months
MechanismInhibits cytokines, complementRemoves AQP4-IgG and complementGenomic immunosuppressionPurine synthesis inhibition
Level of evidence (guidelines)Level CLevel CNo recommendation for acuteLevel B for maintenance

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate high‐dose IV methylprednisolone within 7 days of symptom onset to maximize functional recovery.
• If no meaningful improvement after 3–5 days of steroids, add PLEX within 5–7 days—early PLEX correlates with better neurologic outcomes.
• Avoid relying solely on high‐dose oral prednisone for acute relapses; it’s intended only as a brief taper post‐IV therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering plasma exchange before a trial of high‐dose steroids rather than as salvage therapy.
2. Confusing maintenance immunosuppressants (azathioprine, mycophenolate) with acute relapse treatment.
3. Believing that a slow oral steroid taper alone can control a fulminant NMOSD attack.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Panel for NMOSD Diagnosis (2015): Recommends IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day for 3–5 days as first‐line (Level C) and PLEX for steroid‐refractory cases (Level C).
2. American Academy of Neurology (2019) Practice Guideline: States adjunctive PLEX within 7 days of steroid nonresponse significantly improves 6‐month EDSS outcomes (Recommendation; Level B evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. NMOSD acute management questions commonly test the stepwise use of high‐dose IV corticosteroids followed by PLEX if needed, contrasting acute rescue therapies with long‐term maintenance immunosuppressants. Such questions frequently appear as single‐best-answer formats on neurology board examinations.

question_text: In a pediatric patient with progressive focal seizures, hemiparesis, and MRI evidence of unilateral perisylvian atrophy suggestive of Rasmussen syndrome, which autoantibody has been historically associated with this condition?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Rasmussen syndrome is a chronic, immune‐mediated focal encephalitis typically presenting in children with intractable partial seizures that often secondarily generalize and progressive hemiparesis.
• Neuroimaging reveals unilateral cortical atrophy, frequently involving the perisylvian region, reflecting both neuronal loss and gliosis.
• Although cytotoxic T‐cells predominately mediate neuronal destruction, autoantibodies—most notably against the GluR3 subunit of the AMPA receptor—were first described in a subset of patients and underpin the concept of antibody‐associated encephalitis.

*(~100 words)*

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anti‐NMDA
– Targets NR1 subunit of NMDA receptor; presents with psychiatric symptoms, memory deficits, dyskinesias, autonomic instability.
– Misconception: “All antibody‐mediated encephalitides present with seizures.” Anti‐NMDA encephalitis is diffuse, not focal hemiatrophic.

C. Anti‐GAD
– Directed against glutamic acid decarboxylase 65; associated with stiff‐person syndrome, cerebellar ataxia, limbic encephalitis, refractory temporal lobe epilepsy.
– Does not cause progressive unihemispheric atrophy or motor deficits as in Rasmussen’s.

D. Anti‐CASPR2
– Part of VGKC complex; linked to limbic encephalitis, Morvan syndrome, neuromyotonia.
– Lacks a predilection for focal cortical inflammation or unihemispheric shrinkage.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti‐GluR3Anti‐NMDAAnti‐GAD65Anti‐CASPR2
AntigenAMPA receptor, GluR3 subunitNMDA receptor, NR1 subunitGlutamic acid decarboxylase 65Contactin‐associated protein 2
SyndromeRasmussen encephalitisAnti‐NMDA receptor encephalitisStiff‐person, limbic encephalitisVGKC‐complex encephalitis
Key Clinical FeaturesFocal seizures, hemiparesis, atrophyPsychiatric, dyskinesias, autonomicStiffness, cerebellar signs, temporal lobe epilepsyNeuromyotonia, dysautonomia
MRI FindingsUnilateral cortical atrophyOften normal or T2 hyperintensities limbic regionsMedial temporal T2 hyperintensitiesMesial temporal hyperintensities
Frequency in Condition~25–30% of Rasmussen cases~70% of NMDA‐RE~10–15% of stiff‐person cases~20–40% of VGKC‐encephalitis

Clinical Pearls

1. Rasmussen syndrome typically presents between ages 6–10 with epilepsia partialis continua and progressive hemiparesis; early MRI may show T2 hyperintensities before frank atrophy.
2. Anti‐GluR3 positivity, while supportive, is neither sensitive nor routinely tested; brain biopsy and clinical criteria remain diagnostic gold standards.
3. Immunotherapies (IVIG, steroids, rituximab) can slow progression temporarily, but functional hemispherectomy offers the most definitive seizure control in refractory cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Equating any seizure‐associated antibody with Rasmussen’s—only anti‐GluR3 has historical association.
• Assuming antibody positivity is required; diagnosis is clinical, radiologic, and histopathologic.
• Overlooking hemispherectomy as a treatment due to focus on immunotherapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Graus F. et al., “A clinical approach to diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis,” Lancet Neurol 2016. Recommends against inclusion of low‐sensitivity antibodies (e.g., anti‐GluR3) in core diagnostic criteria (Level IV evidence).
2. ILAE Autoimmune and Inflammatory Epilepsy Task Force Consensus, Epilepsia 2021. States anti‐GluR3 remains a research biomarker; routine panels focus on NMDA, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA(B), AMPAR (subunits 1/2), GAD65 (Consensus Grade C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Progressive involvement of the perisylvian cortex (Rolandic, opercular regions) accounts for motor cortex hyperexcitability, hemiparesis, and aphasia when dominant hemisphere is affected.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Cytotoxic CD8+ T‐cells infiltrate cortex, inducing neuronal apoptosis.
• Anti‐GluR3 antibodies may activate complement, exacerbating neuronal loss.
• Microglial nodules and gliosis reflect ongoing inflammation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: intractable focal seizures ± EPC, progressive hemiparesis.
2. MRI: unilateral cortical swelling → atrophy of perisylvian region.
3. EEG: continuous interictal spikes over one hemisphere.
4. CSF/serum antibody panel: anti‐GluR3 (research), exclude NMDA, LGI1, GAD65.
5. Brain biopsy: confirm T‐cell–mediated encephalitis if diagnosis unclear.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Early MRI may show cortical swelling with hyperintense signal on T2/FLAIR.
• Later stages demonstrate marked hemispheric atrophy with ventricular enlargement and perisylvian prominence.
