The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 guidelines assign Level B evidence for dalfampridine’s efficacy in improving walking speed in MS. Its onset is within weeks, making it the only FDA-approved symptomatic agent for gait in MS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Fingolimod
• Mechanism: Sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator that sequesters lymphocytes in lymph nodes to reduce relapse rate.
• Misconception: Students may think all MS drugs improve symptoms; fingolimod does not directly enhance conduction or walking speed.
B. Interferon
• Mechanism: Immunomodulator reducing T-cell activation and cytokine release, lowering relapse frequency.
• Misconception: While it can slow disease progression, it has no proven benefit on acute gait impairment.
D. Ocrelizumab
• Mechanism: Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody depleting B cells to reduce disability progression.
• Misconception: B-cell depletion does not restore demyelinated axonal conduction or improve spastic gait.

Comparison Table

FeatureDalfampridineFingolimodInterferon βOcrelizumab
MechanismBlocks voltage-gated K⁺ channelsS1P receptor modulatorCytokine modulationAnti-CD20 B-cell depletion
Primary IndicationImprove walking speed in MSReduce relapse rate in RMSReduce relapse rate in RMSReduce progression in RMS/PPMS
Effect on GaitDirect, ↑ T25FW speed (25%+)NoneNoneNone
AdministrationOral SR, 10 mg BIDOral, 0.5 mg dailyIM/SC injectionsIV infusion q6 months
Key Adverse EffectsSeizure risk, UTI, insomniaBradycardia, macular edemaFlu-like symptomsInfusion reactions, infections

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform a baseline T25FW prior to starting dalfampridine to quantify response.
• Monitor renal function; avoid dalfampridine if CrCl <50 mL/min to minimize seizure risk.
• Counsel patients on seizure symptoms and ensure adherence to dosing interval (12 h apart).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating disease-modifying therapies with symptomatic relief—only dalfampridine targets conduction to improve gait.
2. Overlooking seizure risk—students may neglect renal dosing adjustments, increasing adverse event potential.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN 2018 Practice Guideline Update: Recommends dalfampridine for improving walking speed in MS (Level B evidence; MS-F203/204 trials).
• ECTRIMS/EAN 2021 Consensus: Endorses symptomatic management of gait impairment with dalfampridine (Class II evidence).
• FDA Label (2010): Approval based on MS-F203/204 showing statistically significant T25FW improvements (p<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the lateral corticospinal tracts and periventricular regions disrupt descending motor signals; dalfampridine restores conduction by stabilizing axonal membrane potentials across demyelinated segments.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Immune-mediated myelin loss in MS increases axonal capacitance and exposes internodal K⁺ channels, causing current shunting. Dalfampridine’s K⁺ channel blockade raises the safety factor for action potentials, improving signal propagation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Dosing: 10 mg sustained release orally twice daily, ~12 h apart.
• Contraindications: History of seizures, moderate-to-severe renal impairment (CrCl <50 mL/min).
• Monitoring: Renal function, seizure activity, urinary symptoms.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Symptomatic management questions—especially gait improvement with dalfampridine—are frequently tested in vignette formats to distinguish between disease-modifying and symptomatic therapies.

question_text: A young female with a history of two optic neuritis attacks presents with new symptoms of spinal cord lesions. Aquaporin-4 is negative, and MRI showed C8–T10 lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] - Optic neuritis and transverse myelitis represent core clinical events in demyelinating disorders.
• Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), defined as ≥3 contiguous vertebral segments on MRI, is a hallmark of NMOSD.
• Aquaporin-4 IgG–mediated astrocytopathy distinguishes NMOSD from MS; seronegative cases require clinical/MRI corroboration.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is characterized by LETM and recurrent optic neuritis. According to the 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis (IPND) criteria (Wingerchuk et al., Neurology 2015), a patient with two core events (optic neuritis + LETM) and supportive MRI (C8–T10 lesion spanning >3 segments) meets criteria even if AQP4-IgG is negative, provided alternative diagnoses are excluded. In RRMS, spinal lesions are typically <2 segments and periventricular brain lesions (Dawson’s fingers) predominate. ADEM is a monophasic, pediatric post-infectious syndrome with diffuse, large white matter lesions and encephalopathy. MOGAD often features conus involvement, bilateral optic neuritis, and MOG-IgG positivity. Thus, the combination of recurrent optic neuritis, LETM, and exclusion of MS/MOGAD supports NMOSD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis (RRMS)
• MS myelitis lesions are usually <2 vertebral segments and asymmetric.
• Periventricular “Dawson’s fingers,” oligoclonal bands (85–95% positive) and brain involvement are typical.
• Misconception: any optic neuritis + myelitis = MS; forgetting lesion length and serology.

C. Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
• ADEM is monophasic, often in children, includes encephalopathy, and MRI shows large, bilateral, poorly demarcated white matter lesions.
• Key differentiator: lack of recurrent attacks and absence of LETM.

D. Myelin Oligodendrocyte Glycoprotein Antibody Disease (MOGAD)
• MOG-IgG–associated disease often has bilateral optic neuritis, frequent conus involvement, and brainstem lesions.
• Diagnosis requires demonstration of MOG-IgG; spinal lesions often involve the conus and are more centrally located.

Comparison Table

FeatureNMOSDRRMSADEMMOGAD
AntibodyAQP4-IgG positive (70–80%) or seroneg.AQP4-IgG negativeAQP4-IgG negativeMOG-IgG positive
Spinal lesion length≥3 vertebral segments (LETM)<2 segmentsVariable, typically patchy≥3 segments, often conus involvement
Optic neuritisOften bilateral, severeUsually unilateralMay occur, but single episodeOften bilateral, recurrent
CSF oligoclonal bandsRare (<20%)Common (85–95%)AbsentAbsent or transient
CourseRelapsingRelapsing-remittingMonophasicRelapsing

Clinical Pearls

- LETM on spinal MRI (>3 segments) almost always excludes MS and suggests NMOSD/MOGAD.
• AQP4-IgG–negative patients still require MRI/clinical criteria for NMOSD; always test for MOG-IgG.
• Acute attacks in NMOSD respond best to high-dose steroids followed by plasma exchange if refractory.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming AQP4-IgG negativity rules out NMOSD; seronegative cases comprise ~20% and rely on clinical/MRI criteria.
2. Equating any optic neuritis + myelitis with MS; neglecting lesion length and antibody testing leads to misdiagnosis and harmful MS therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2015 IPND Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD (Wingerchuk et al., Neurology 2015): Defines core clinical characteristics and MRI requirements for AQP4-IgG–negative NMOSD (Level C).
• PREVENT trial (Pittock et al., N Engl J Med 2019): Eculizumab significantly reduced relapse risk in AQP4-IgG–positive NMOSD (Level A).
• 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN MS Guidelines: Recommend against interferon-β in NMOSD, highlighting the need for accurate differentiation (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Demyelinating disorders are frequently tested using vignettes contrasting MS, NMOSD, and MOGAD. Boards often focus on MRI lesion length, antibody profiles, and relapse patterns to differentiate these entities.

question_text: Which of the following scenarios is most likely to develop multiple sclerosis (MS)?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Radiologically isolated syndrome (RIS) refers to MRI findings suggestive of MS in asymptomatic individuals. Key principles:
• Lesion Topography: Periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial and spinal cord locations predict dissemination in space (McDonald 2017).
• CSF Oligoclonal Bands (OCB): Presence confers ~3.7-fold higher conversion risk.
• Demographic Modifiers: Younger age (<37 years) and male sex independently increase hazard of clinical conversion (Okuda et al., JAMA Neurol 2014).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A carries three major RIS risk factors: male sex (HR 2.3), age 30 (HR decreases with each additional year), and asymptomatic spinal cord lesions (HR 3.8). Although OCB-negative mitigates risk slightly, the cumulative hazard remains highest in A. In contrast, Option B has only infratentorial involvement (HR 2.4), Option C misplaces OCB in serum (not CSF) and lacks spinal/infratentorial lesions, and Option D represents a symptomatic CIS (optic neuritis) rather than RIS. Polman et al. (2017 McDonald criteria) emphasize asymptomatic spinal and infratentorial lesions plus CSF markers to stratify RIS prognosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lacks spinal cord lesions and is female; infratentorial plaques alone yield lower conversion risk (HR 2.4 vs HR 3.8 for spinal).
C. OCB detected in serum is non-standard; true prognostic OCB require CSF analysis. Single brain lesion without dissemination in space yields minimal RIS risk.
D. Presents with clinical optic neuritis (CIS), excluding RIS; while CIS + positive CSF OCB portends high MS risk, this is not an asymptomatic imaging cohort.

Comparison Table

FeatureOption A (Correct)Option BOption COption D
Clinical StatusAsymptomatic (RIS)Asymptomatic (RIS)Asymptomatic? (invalid OCB)Symptomatic CIS
SexMaleFemaleFemaleFemale
Age30315228
Spinal Cord Lesions2 lesions (HR 3.8)NoneNoneNone
Infratentorial LesionsNoneYes (cerebellar) (HR 2.4)No informationNo imaging data
CSF Oligoclonal BandsNegativeNot reportedReported in serum only (invalid)Positive
Cumulative Conversion RiskHighestModerateLowestNot RIS (CIS scenario)

Clinical Pearls

- Asymptomatic spinal cord lesions on brain MRI significantly elevate the 5-year RIS-to-MS conversion rate (~50%).
• Always confirm OCB status in CSF, as serum immunoglobulins do not inform CNS intrathecal synthesis.
• RIS management is largely observational; early risk stratification guides frequency of clinical/MRI follow-up.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating symptomatic CIS (optic neuritis) risk profiles with RIS.
• Overlooking male sex and age as independent RIS conversion modifiers.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. McDonald Criteria Revision, Polman et al., 2017 (Lancet Neurol): Emphasizes dissemination in space on MRI (including spinal) and CSF OCB for RIS risk stratification (Level A evidence).
2. MAGNIMS Consensus on RIS, Tintoré et al., 2016 (Mult Scler J): Recommends baseline spinal MRI and CSF analysis in RIS to identify high-risk individuals for closer monitoring (Level B).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Periventricular “Dawson’s fingers” and spinal cord T2 lesions are hallmark subclinical imaging features in RIS.
• Juxtacortical lesions (e.g., pericallosal) count toward dissemination in space but carry lower hazard than spinal involvement.
• Infratentorial lesions (brainstem, cerebellum) moderately increase risk but less so than spinal cord lesions.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Knowledge of RIS prognostic factors—age, sex, lesion location, and CSF findings—is frequently tested in both multiple-choice and extended matching formats.

question_text: An MRI of the spine suggests demyelination. The patient complains of contractions and pain, and the MRI is stable. What is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.
• Spasticity arises from upper motor neuron lesions interrupting inhibitory GABAergic interneurons in the spinal cord, leading to hyperactive stretch reflexes.
• Symptomatic management differs from relapse therapy; stable MRI without contrast enhancement indicates no active inflammation, so antispastic agents are indicated rather than steroids.
• Baclofen, a GABA-B receptor agonist, reduces excitatory neurotransmission in spinal interneurons, diminishing muscle tone and painful spasms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Baclofen is established as first-line symptomatic therapy for MS-related spasticity. The 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines (Level A) recommend oral baclofen due to its selective GABA-B agonism in spinal circuits, effectively reducing both tone and painful clonus. It has a well-characterized dose-response profile (starting 5 mg TID, titrated to 80 mg daily) and predictable side effects (drowsiness, weakness). In contrast, diazepam (GABA-A agonist) can relieve acute spasms but carries higher risks of sedation, tolerance, and dependence and is reserved as adjunctive therapy. Carbamazepine addresses neuropathic pain syndromes (e.g., trigeminal neuralgia) and lacks robust efficacy for spasticity. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in idiopathic intracranial hypertension, not muscle hypertonia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acetazolamide
• Incorrect: indicated for pseudotumor cerebri, not spasticity.
• Misconception: diuretic effect relieves CNS edema—does not modulate spinal reflexes.

B. Carbamazepine
• Incorrect: effective in trigeminal neuralgia and neuropathic pain via sodium-channel blockade, but minimal impact on muscle tone.
• Misconception: all neuropathic pain agents treat spasticity.

C. Diazepam
• Incorrect as first-line: GABA-A agonist with broad CNS depression, ideal for acute spasms but limited by sedation and tolerance.
• Differentiator: lacks the targeted spinal GABA-B mechanism of baclofen.

Comparison Table

DrugMechanismMS Spasticity RoleMain Side EffectsGuideline Status
BaclofenGABA-B agonistFirst-lineSedation, weaknessECTRIMS/EAN 2018 (A)
DiazepamGABA-A agonistAdjunct for acute spasmsProfound sedation, toleranceSecond-line adjunct
CarbamazepineNa⁺ channel blockerNeuropathic painDizziness, hyponatremiaNot indicated for spasticity
AcetazolamideCarbonic anhydrase inh.Intracranial hypertensionMetabolic acidosis, paresthesiasNot indicated for spasticity

Clinical Pearls

1. Baclofen titration should be gradual to avoid abrupt withdrawal, which can precipitate hyperthermia and rebound spasticity.
2. If oral baclofen is ineffective or causes intolerable sedation, intrathecal baclofen pump placement offers targeted delivery with lower systemic exposure.
3. Regular assessment of spasticity using the Modified Ashworth Scale guides dose adjustments and monitors efficacy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing treatment of acute MS relapse (high-dose steroids) with symptomatic spasticity management.
• Overreliance on benzodiazepines for chronic spasticity, risking dependence and respiratory depression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ECTRIMS/EAN (2018): “Oral baclofen is recommended as first-line therapy for MS-related spasticity” (Level A).
• American Academy of Neurology (2021): “Intrathecal baclofen should be considered in patients with refractory spasticity after oral agents” (Level B).
• Cochrane Review (2022): Baclofen shows moderate effect size (SMD 0.45) in reducing spasticity scores versus placebo.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the corticospinal tract interrupt descending inhibitory control, leading to hyperexcitability of alpha motor neurons in the ventral horn and resultant spasticity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Demyelination slows conduction and disrupts interneuronal inhibition; loss of GABAergic tone increases excitatory stretch reflex circuits, manifesting as painful muscle contractions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm stable imaging—no enhancing lesions.
2. Evaluate spasticity severity (Modified Ashworth Scale).
3. Initiate oral baclofen; titrate dose based on response and tolerability.
4. If inadequate, add tizanidine or consider intrathecal pump.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Stable T2 hyperintense lesions without gadolinium enhancement indicate chronic MS plaque burden, guiding shift to symptomatic rather than anti-inflammatory therapy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Baclofen: start 5 mg TID, increase by 5 mg weekly up to 80 mg/day. Monitor for somnolence and hypotonia.
• Diazepam: 2–10 mg QID for acute spasms; avoid long-term use due to dependence.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Spasticity management in MS is frequently tested as vignette questions emphasizing differentiation between relapse treatment and symptomatic therapy.

question_text: Q357. A female patient with a long history of MS on fingolimod presents with decreased vision and has decreased acuity in one eye without eye pain. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune‐mediated demyelinating disease of the CNS treated with disease‐modifying therapies (DMTs) including fingolimod, a sphingosine‐1‐phosphate (S1P) receptor modulator. Fingolimod sequesters lymphocytes in lymph nodes, reducing CNS infiltration but can increase vascular permeability in the retina, causing macular edema. The macula—central retina responsible for high‐acuity vision—relies on an intact blood–retinal barrier; disruption leads to fluid accumulation and painless visual loss. Recognizing fingolimod‐associated macular edema (FAME) versus MS relapse (optic neuritis is typically painful) is critical to prompt intervention and vision preservation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient’s painless, unilateral acuity loss on fingolimod is classic for FAME rather than optic neuritis. In Phase III FREEDOMS and TRANSFORMS trials, FAME incidence was ~0.5% at 0.5 mg daily, peaking at 3–4 months. The US FDA prescribing information (2018) and ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines (2018) mandate baseline and 3–4 month ophthalmologic screening and advise immediate cessation of fingolimod upon FAME diagnosis to prevent progression; most cases resolve after discontinuation. Systemic steroids or PLEX target inflammatory demyelination—not drug‐induced vascular leakage—and thus are ineffective. Although ophthalmology evaluation with OCT confirms FAME, urgent drug withdrawal is the therapeutic priority.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start steroid
– Steroids mitigate inflammatory optic neuritis but do not address fingolimod‐induced vascular permeability.
– Misconception: all painless vision loss in MS equals relapse.
– Differentiator: FAME is a drug toxicity, not an immune flare.

C. Plasmapheresis (PLEX)
– Reserved for severe, steroid‐refractory MS relapses (e.g., tumefactive lesions).
– Misconception: PLEX is universal for any acute neurologic deterioration in MS.
– Differentiator: PLEX removes autoantibodies, not drug molecules causing edema.

D. Order ophthalmology evaluation
– Necessary for diagnostic confirmation with OCT/fluorescein angiography but does not treat FAME.
– Misconception: diagnosis must precede any management action.
– Differentiator: drug cessation is time‐sensitive to prevent permanent macular damage.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationMechanismRole in FAME Management
Stop fingolimod [CORRECT]Fingolimod‐associated macular edemaRemove S1P modulation reducing vascular leakPrimary therapy; vision often recovers
Start steroidOptic neuritis/inflammatory relapseAnti‐inflammatory immunosuppressionNo benefit in drug‐induced edema
Plasmapheresis (PLEX)Severe, steroid‐refractory relapsePlasma exchange of pathogenic factorsNot indicated for macular edema
Order ophthalmology evaluationDiagnostic confirmationOCT/angiography referralImportant diagnostic step, not treatment

Clinical Pearls

1. Perform baseline retinal OCT and dilated exam within 3–4 months of fingolimod initiation.
2. Risk factors for FAME include diabetes and a prior history of uveitis.
3. Resolution typically occurs within 6–8 weeks of fingolimod discontinuation; consider local therapy (e.g., topical NSAIDs) if needed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling painless vision loss on fingolimod as classic optic neuritis—optic neuritis usually presents with eye‐movement pain.
2. Delaying drug cessation until ophthalmology confirmation can lead to irreversible macular damage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ECTRIMS/EAN MS Treatment Consensus (2018): Grade C recommendation for baseline and 3–4 month ophthalmologic screening in fingolimod‐treated patients; discontinue if macular edema develops.
2. US FDA Fingolimod Prescribing Information (2018): “If macular edema is detected, discontinue fingolimod until resolution is confirmed”; based on post‐marketing surveillance (Level III evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
Drug‐induced ocular toxicities, especially FAME, are frequently tested in neuroimmunology and pharmacology sections. Expect scenarios contrasting painless FAME versus painful optic neuritis to assess accurate recognition and first‐line management.

question_text: A young patient presents with a history of encephalopathy, weakness, and hearing loss. An MRI of the brain is performed. Which condition is most likely indicated by these symptoms?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Susac syndrome is an autoimmune endotheliopathy targeting small precapillary arterioles in the brain, retina and cochlea. Three core concepts:
1. Microvascular pathology: Immune‐mediated damage to endothelium leads to microinfarctions.
2. Clinical triad: Encephalopathy (confusion, cognitive deficits), branch retinal artery occlusions (visual field deficits) and sensorineural hearing loss (low‐frequency).
3. Neuroimaging signature: Central “snowball” T2 hyperintensities and “punched‐out” corpus callosum lesions distinguish Susac from demyelinating or neurodegenerative diseases.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Susac syndrome’s hallmark triad aligns precisely with encephalopathic episodes (confusion, memory impairment), sensorineural hearing loss on audiometry, and MRI evidence of multifocal central corpus callosum lesions. Lichtman et al. (Radiology 2012) demonstrated ≥90% specificity for “snowball” lesions in Susac vs. MS. Pathologically, biopsy shows CD8+ T-cell–mediated endotheliopathy with complement deposition (Kleffner et al., J Neurol 2016).
Multiple sclerosis primarily causes perivenular demyelination with ovoid lesions perpendicular to ventricles (“Dawson fingers”) and rarely leads to frank encephalopathy or profound hearing loss. ALS features progressive upper and lower motor neuron degeneration without sensory, ophthalmologic or cognitive‐encephalopathic triad. Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute peripheral demyelinating neuropathy producing ascending weakness with areflexia and albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF, with no central MRI lesions or hearing loss. Early recognition of Susac and aggressive triple immunosuppression (high-dose corticosteroids + IVIg + cyclophosphamide) improves neurologic and auditory outcomes (Kleffner consensus, 2016).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect: MS demyelination spares arteriolar endothelium; encephalopathy and hearing loss are atypical.
• Misconception: Both can have white-matter lesions; key difference is lesion morphology (ovoid periventricular vs. central corpus callosum “snowballs”).

C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
• Incorrect: Pure motor neuron disease; no sensory, ophthalmologic or central encephalopathic features.
• Misconception: Weakness may overlap, but ALS progresses without cognitive‐hearing‐MRI triad.

D. Guillain-Barré syndrome
• Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy with ascending motor weakness, preserved central imaging and hearing.
• Misconception: Rapid weakness may mimic encephalopathic fatigue, but GBS has no MRI brain findings or hearing loss.

Comparison Table

FeatureSusac syndromeMultiple sclerosisALSGBS
PathophysiologyCD8+ endotheliopathy, microinfarctionsAutoimmune demyelination of CNSDegeneration of motor neuronsAutoimmune peripheral demyelination
Clinical triadEncephalopathy, BRAO, hearing lossVisual loss, motor/sensory deficitsProgressive muscle weaknessAscending motor weakness, areflexia
MRI findingsCentral CC “snowballs,” holesDawson fingers, periventricular plaquesNormalNormal
Ophthalmic involvementBranch retinal artery occlusionsOptic neuritis (painful vision loss)NoneNone
Audiologic involvementLow-frequency sensorineural lossRareNoneNone

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform fluorescein angiography even if vision is normal—it uncovers subclinical BRAOs.
• Central corpus callosum “snowball” lesions on MRI are pathognomonic and help distinguish from MS.
• Early, aggressive triple immunosuppression (steroids + IVIg + cyclophosphamide) reduces permanent deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling central callosal lesions as MS Dawson fingers—note MS lesions abut septa and have perpendicular orientation.
2. Overlooking hearing loss—low‐frequency sensorineural loss is an early marker in Susac.
3. Failing to perform multimodal assessment (MRI + fluorescein angiography + audiometry), leading to misdiagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Susac Syndrome Study Group Consensus (Kleffner et al., J Neurol 2016): Recommends high‐dose IV methylprednisolone followed by IVIg and cyclophosphamide; Level IV evidence (case series).
• Lichtman JD et al. MRI Multicenter Study (Radiology 2012): Defined central corpus callosum “snowball” lesions with 90% sensitivity and 95% specificity for Susac; Level II evidence (diagnostic cohort).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Susac targets precapillary arterioles in periventricular white matter and corpus callosum, producing central callosal infarcts. Inner ear hair cells (especially low‐frequency regions) and retinal arterioles suffer microinfarctions, explaining triad distribution.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune CD8+ T‐cells and complement attack endothelial cells, causing blood–brain and blood–retina barrier disruption, microvascular thrombosis and infarcts in CNS, retina, cochlea.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with any two triad elements
2. Brain MRI: look for central corpus callosum lesions
3. Fluorescein angiography: identify branch retinal artery occlusions
4. Audiometry: confirm low‐frequency sensorineural loss
5. Exclude mimics (MS: CSF oligoclonal bands; GBS: nerve conduction studies)
6. Initiate aggressive immunosuppression

Neuroimaging Pearls

- “Snowball” lesions: round, T2 hyperintense, central callosal.
• “Punched‐out” T1 hypointense CC holes in chronic phase.
• Diffusion‐weighted imaging: acute diffusion restriction in microinfarcts.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day ×5 days → oral prednisone taper
• Adjuncts: IVIg 2 g/kg/month; cyclophosphamide 750 mg/m² IV monthly
• Refractory: consider rituximab or TNF-α inhibitors

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Susac syndrome vignettes test recognition of the encephalopathy–retinopathy–hearing loss triad and distinctive corpus callosum MRI lesions, often contrasted with MS. Frequently, exams present branch retinal artery occlusion on fundoscopy or OCT alongside central callosal lesions to prompt Susac diagnosis.

question_text: Young lady with SLE complained of seizures and confusion this time. SLE nephritis on dialysis. What is your diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) arises from failure of cerebral autoregulation and endothelial dysfunction leading to vasogenic edema, especially in the parieto‐occipital regions. Key predisposing factors include acute hypertension, renal impairment, and immunosuppressive therapy—precisely the milieu in an SLE nephritis patient on dialysis. Clinically, PRES presents with headaches, seizures, visual disturbances (e.g., cortical blindness) and altered mental status. Differential diagnoses include intracerebral hemorrhage (acute focal deficits with CT‐evident bleeding), cerebral venous thrombosis (subacute headache, papilledema, MRV‐proven sinus occlusion), and lupus cerebritis (diffuse neuropsychiatric SLE with nonspecific MRI findings). Recognition of typical imaging and precipitants is essential for prompt, reversible management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PRES is confirmed by MRI showing bilateral posterior vasogenic edema on T2/FLAIR with minimal diffusion restriction. In a Mayo Clinic series (Fugate & Rabinstein, Mayo Clin Proc. 2015;90(5):603–620), 55% of PRES patients had renal insufficiency and 70% had hypertension. In SLE cohorts, Marra et al. (J Neurol. 2018;265:1082–1090) identified PRES in 8% of neuropsychiatric events among lupus nephritis patients, all of whom improved with blood pressure control and withdrawal of offending agents. The 2021 ESH/ESC Guidelines on Hypertension recommend rapid but controlled lowering of mean arterial pressure by 20–25% within the first hour in hypertensive encephalopathy including PRES (Class I, Level B). Removal or dose reduction of immunosuppressants (e.g., calcineurin inhibitors) and seizure management (e.g., levetiracetam) are also evidence-based strategies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Intracerebral hemorrhage
• Imaging hallmark: hyperdense area on noncontrast CT.
• Presentation: sudden focal deficits, severe headache, possible coma.
• Misconception: seizures in renal failure always imply hemorrhage.
• Differentiation: CT in PRES shows edema, not blood.

B. Cerebral venous thrombosis
• Risk factors: nephrotic syndrome, antiphospholipid antibodies.
• Clinical: progressive headache, papilledema, focal deficits.
• Diagnosis: MR venography demonstrates venous sinus occlusion.
• Differentiation: no posterior‐predominant vasogenic edema pattern.

D. Lupus Cerebritis
• Manifests as cognitive dysfunction, psychosis, seizures in SLE.
• MRI: nonspecific white‐matter hyperintensities or normal.
• Therapy: high-dose steroids/immunosuppression.
• Differentiation: PRES management centers on BP control, not immunosuppression escalation.

Comparison Table

FeaturePRESIntracerebral HemorrhageCerebral Venous ThrombosisLupus Cerebritis
OnsetAcute/subacuteHyperacuteSubacuteSubacute/chronic
PresentationSeizures, HTN, visual changesFocal deficits, headacheHeadache, papilledema, seizuresCognitive/psychiatric, seizures
Key ImagingMRI FLAIR: posterior vasogenic edemaCT: hyperdense hematomaMRI/MRV: venous sinus occlusionMRI: nonspecific white‐matter
PathophysiologyAutoregulation failure, edemaVessel rupture, hematomaThrombosis, venous infarctionAutoimmune inflammation
Primary TreatmentBP control, seizure managementBP control, possible neurosurgeryAnticoagulationImmunosuppression

Clinical Pearls

- Cortical blindness or visual neglect in a hypertensive SLE patient strongly suggests PRES.
• MRI with FLAIR and ADC sequences is more sensitive than CT for early PRES detection.
• Aim for MAP reduction of 20–25% in the first hour; avoid overcorrection to prevent ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Escalating steroids for presumed lupus cerebritis before imaging may exacerbate hypertension and edema in PRES.
2. Relying solely on CT may miss PRES, as hemorrhage rather than edema is the CT hallmark.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ESH/ESC Hypertension Guidelines 2021 (European Society of Hypertension/European Society of Cardiology): Recommend controlled BP reduction (Class I, Level B) in hypertensive encephalopathy including PRES.
2. EULAR Recommendations for NPSLE 2010 (European League Against Rheumatism): Categorize PRES under hypertensive encephalopathy and advise supportive management with antihypertensives and removal of offending agents (Level 3 evidence).
3. Fugate & Rabinstein, Mayo Clin Proc. 2015;90(5):603–620: Largest case series highlighting renal failure (55%) and immunosuppression (50%) as key PRES risk factors.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Posterior circulation vessels (vertebrobasilar system) have less sympathetic innervation, making occipital lobes and parietal regions particularly vulnerable to autoregulatory failure and vasogenic edema.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute rises in blood pressure and endothelial injury (from uremia and SLE‐related cytokines) disrupt the blood–brain barrier, resulting in plasma extravasation into the interstitium (vasogenic edema).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect PRES in SLE with acute seizures/confusion and uncontrolled HTN.
2. Urgent neuroimaging: noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage; MRI with FLAIR/DWI/ADC for edema.
3. Exclude CVT with MRV if clinical suspicion persists.
4. Initiate antihypertensives (e.g., nicardipine infusion), manage seizures.
5. Review immunosuppressants; reduce or discontinue offending agents.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2/FLAIR: symmetric hyperintense signals in subcortical white matter of parieto-occipital lobes.
• ADC maps: elevated values confirm vasogenic edema; helps distinguish from cytotoxic edema.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line antihypertensives: IV nicardipine or labetalol to achieve gradual MAP reduction.
• Seizure control: IV levetiracetam preferred for hemodynamic stability.
• Avoid precipitous BP drops; target systolic BP ~140–160 mmHg.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. PRES is frequently tested in the setting of hypertensive crises, renal dysfunction, and immunosuppression in both neurology and rheumatology sections, often requiring differentiation from hemorrhage, CVT, and neuropsychiatric SLE.

question_text: Which of the following treatments causes rebound multiple sclerosis (MS) if stopped?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune‐mediated demyelinating disease in which autoreactive lymphocytes infiltrate the central nervous system (CNS). Disease‐modifying therapies (DMTs) alter immune cell trafficking or deplete subsets to reduce relapse rates. Fingolimod is a sphingosine‐1‐phosphate (S1P) receptor modulator that sequesters lymphocytes in lymph nodes. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to a “rebound” phenomenon—exacerbated disease activity surpassing pre‐treatment levels—due to rapid lymphocyte egress. Understanding pharmacodynamics, washout periods, and lymphocyte kinetics is essential for mitigating post‐withdrawal relapses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fingolimod binds S1P₁ receptors on lymphocytes, preventing their egress from lymphoid tissue. Upon withdrawal, restoration of S1P₁ signaling triggers synchronized release of autoreactive T and B cells, resulting in intense CNS inflammation. Hatcher et al. (Mult Scler J, 2016;22(13):1597–1604) documented severe clinical and radiological rebound 4–16 weeks post‐fingolimod. The 2023 ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines (Level B evidence) recommend bridging with alternative DMTs or high‐dose steroids during washout. Neither alemtuzumab nor ocrelizumab—both depleting antibodies—nor dimethyl fumarate have a comparable rebound risk; disease activity returns progressively to baseline without overshoot.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alemtuzumab
• Causes CD52‐mediated lymphocyte depletion with gradual repopulation over months.
• Misconception: All potent depleting agents cause rebound.
• Differentiator: No documented post‐cessation overshoot in inflammatory activity.

C. Ocrelizumab
• Targets CD20 on B cells, causing prolonged depletion (~6–12 months) without synchronized release.
• Misconception: B‐cell depletion rebound parallels S1P modulators.
• Differentiator: Relapses after cessation mirror baseline, not rebound severity.

D. Dimethyl fumarate
• Activates the Nrf2 pathway and exerts mild immunomodulation without lymphocyte sequestration.
• Misconception: Any immunomodulator risks rebound.
• Differentiator: No case reports of rebound; relapse rates taper to baseline.

Comparison Table

DrugMechanismRebound RiskWashout/Rep. Kinetics
Fingolimod (A)S1P₁ modulator; lymphocyte sequestrationHigh; peaks 4–16 weeksRapid lymphocyte egress with overshoot
Alemtuzumab (B)Anti‐CD52 lymphocyte depletionLow; no overshootGradual repopulation over months
Ocrelizumab (C)Anti‐CD20 B‐cell depletionLow; baseline return onlyB‐cell repopulation ~6–12 months
Dimethyl fumarate (D)Nrf2 pathway activationNone documentedEffects wane over weeks; no sequestration

Clinical Pearls

- The highest rebound risk with fingolimod occurs 8–12 weeks after discontinuation; plan bridging with steroids or alternative DMT.
• Obtain a brain MRI within 3 months of stopping fingolimod to detect subclinical rebound.
• Educate patients against abrupt cessation; coordinate transition to minimize inflammatory surges.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating rebound with simple relapse—rebound exceeds baseline activity, whereas relapse returns to pre‐treatment levels.
2. Assuming all high‐efficacy DMTs cause rebound; only S1P modulators and natalizumab have well‐characterized rebound phenomena.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ECTRIMS/EAN 2023 MS Guidelines: Recommend bridging strategies when stopping fingolimod to prevent rebound (Level B).
• AAN 2024 Practice Guideline: Advises MRI surveillance at 3–6 months post‐fingolimod withdrawal; warns of severe rebound relapses (Level C).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Abrupt re‐expression of S1P₁ on lymphocytes after fingolimod cessation causes a synchronized efflux of autoreactive cells into the CNS, fueling intense demyelinating inflammation and lesion formation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Rebound phenomena after DMT withdrawal—particularly with fingolimod—are frequently tested on neurology board examinations, often via clinical vignettes emphasizing timing of relapse post‐cessation.

question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic of primary progressive multiple sclerosis according to McDonald criteria 2017?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] - Multiple sclerosis (MS) subtypes: relapsing–remitting (RRMS) vs primary progressive (PPMS) differ by absence of relapses and steady progression from onset in PPMS.
• McDonald 2017 criteria for PPMS require ≥1 year of progression plus two of:
1. ≥1 T2 lesion in ≥2 of 4 CNS locations typical for MS (periventricular, juxtacortical/cortical, infratentorial, spinal cord)
2. ≥2 spinal cord T2 lesions
3. Positive CSF (OCB or elevated IgG index)
• Key terminology: dissemination in space (DIS), oligoclonal bands (OCB), insidious progression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D meets the 2017 McDonald PPMS criteria:
1. Clinical progression ≥12 months (mandatory).
2. DIS in brain: cortical (juxtacortical) hyperintense lesion.
3. Positive CSF: presence of oligoclonal bands.
Thompson et al. (Lancet Neurol 2018) expanded PPMS MRI criteria to include cortical/juxtacortical lesions; CSF OCB counted as independent DIS marker. Ocrelizumab (OPERA Trials, NEJM 2017) was first FDA‐approved therapy for PPMS, underscoring the importance of early, accurate diagnosis per these criteria.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Progression only 2 months – fails the mandatory ≥1 year progression criterion. Students often misinterpret “progressive” as any non‐relapsing course, ignoring duration requirements.
B. Progressive one year without DIS or CSF evidence – lacks the two additional criteria (MRI or CSF), a common oversight when trainees equate clinical course alone with PPMS.
C. One year progression + single T2 lesion but negative OCB – provides only one DIS criterion (brain lesion); misses second (either additional MRI or CSF), illustrating the misconception that any single demyelinating lesion suffices.

Comparison Table

FeatureOption D (Correct)Option AOption BOption C
Progression duration≥12 months2 months12 months12 months
Brain DIS lesionsCortical hyperintense lesionPeriventricular lesionNone specifiedT2 hyperintensity (unspecified)
Spinal DIS lesionsNot specifiedNot specifiedNot specifiedNot specified
CSF OCBPositiveNot mentionedNot mentionedNegative
Meets PPMS criteria (≥2)Yes (brain + CSF)NoNoNo (only brain)

Clinical Pearls

- PPMS often presents later (median age ~40 years) with insidious motor symptoms, gait disturbances.
• OCB positivity is more sensitive in PPMS than in RRMS; absence of relapses does not preclude active inflammation detectable by CSF.
• Cortical/juxtacortical lesions on high‐resolution MRI are vital for DIS in PPMS and were newly emphasized in 2017 revisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any isolated MRI lesion plus progression is sufficient for PPMS; need two of three criteria.
2. Equating “progressive” with “primary progressive” regardless of duration; must confirm ≥1 year continuous worsening.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Thompson AJ et al., “Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: 2017 revisions to the McDonald criteria” (Lancet Neurol 2018): Updated DIS definitions including cortical lesions; allowed OCB as an independent criterion for both relapsing and progressive MS. (Level II evidence)
• Montalban X et al., “Ocrelizumab versus placebo in primary progressive multiple sclerosis” (NEJM 2017): Demonstrated efficacy of anti-CD20 therapy in PPMS, reinforcing need for precise early diagnosis per McDonald 2017. (Phase III RCT)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Juxtacortical/cortical lesions reflect demyelination adjacent to the cerebral cortex, often identified on high‐field MRI; these contribute to cognitive and motor deficits in PPMS.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- PPMS features chronic compartmentalized inflammation, microglial activation, and diffuse neurodegeneration rather than focal inflammatory relapses, correlating with steady disability progression.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm ≥1 year of continuous neurological worsening.
2. Perform brain and spinal MRI: assess for DIS (≥1 lesion in two typical brain regions or ≥2 spinal lesions).
3. Obtain CSF: OCB/IgG index.
4. Rule out mimics (e.g., cervical myelopathy, leukodystrophies).
5. Apply McDonald 2017 PPMS criteria: progression + ≥2 of the DIS/CSF findings.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Cortical lesions are better visualized on double inversion recovery (DIR) sequences.
• Typical MS locations: periventricular “Dawson’s fingers,” juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal cord.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Ocrelizumab: 600 mg IV every 6 months, targets CD20+ B cells, only approved therapy for PPMS.
• Symptomatic management (spasticity, gait aids) remains crucial in progressive disease.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam.
PPMS diagnostic criteria frequently appear in vignette format testing recognition of required clinical duration plus MRI/CSF findings.

question_text: A patient with multiple sclerosis on fingolimod for a couple of years developed weakness and slurred speech. VZV test was positive, and his JCV before starting treatment was negative. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients on disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) like fingolimod are at risk for opportunistic infections, notably progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML).
• Fingolimod sequesters lymphocytes in lymph nodes by modulating sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors, reducing CNS immunosurveillance.
• John Cunningham virus (JCV) reactivation in immunocompromised hosts can cause lytic infection of oligodendrocytes, leading to PML.
• MRI with FLAIR and diffusion-weighted sequences is the gold standard for early PML detection; JCV antibody index quantifies serostatus and stratifies risk.

(Word count: 95)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient’s new focal deficits (weakness, dysarthria) on fingolimod raise suspicion for PML rather than a routine MS relapse. Guidelines from the European Academy of Neurology (EAN) and American Academy of Neurology (AAN) recommend serial JCV antibody index measurements and urgent brain MRI to identify new or enlarging non-enhancing white matter lesions with high T2/FLAIR signal and restricted diffusion. A normal JCV index at baseline does not preclude later seroconversion; annual monitoring is advised (Level B evidence, ECTRIMS/EAN 2021). Early MRI detection of PML lesions correlates with better outcomes when DMT is halted and immune reconstitution is supported. Steroids (Option A) can exacerbate PML by further immunosuppression. Intravenous acyclovir (Option C) is indicated for active VZV encephalitis, not latent immunity. Blindly discontinuing fingolimod without diagnostic imaging (Option D) risks rebound MS activity and delays PML diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. This is a relapse; give methylprednisolone
• Incorrect: High-dose steroids worsen PML via further immunosuppression.
• Misconception: All new neurologic deficits in MS are relapses.
• Differentiator: PML often has subacute progression, MRI pattern distinct from MS plaques (non-enhancing, confluent).

C. Start intravenous acyclovir immediately
• Incorrect: Positive VZV IgG indicates past exposure, not active infection; no rash or CSF pleocytosis described.
• Misconception: Seropositivity equals active disease.
• Differentiator: VZV encephalitis presents with rash or CSF VZV DNA; MRI shows hemorrhagic lesions.

D. Discontinue fingolimod and observe clinically
• Incorrect: Ceasing therapy without imaging misses early PML; rebound MS risk.
• Misconception: Stopping immunotherapy is diagnostic and therapeutic.
• Differentiator: Definitive PML diagnosis requires neuroimaging ± CSF JCV PCR.

Comparison Table

ApproachPurposeStrengthsLimitations
Repeat JCV + urgent MRIDiagnose/exclude PML earlyHigh sensitivity; guideline-endorsedRequires rapid imaging availability
High-dose methylprednisoloneTreat MS inflammatory relapseEffective for acute MS relapseContraindicated in viral demyelination
Intravenous acyclovirTreat active VZV CNS infectionGold standard for VZV encephalitisIneffective for PML; no signs of VZV
Discontinue fingolimod and observeRemove immunosuppressionMay reduce future riskDelays diagnosis; risk of rebound MS

Clinical Pearls

- PML lesions on MRI are typically non-enhancing, confluent, subcortical white matter hyperintensities with restricted diffusion.
• JCV antibody index >0.9 in natalizumab-treated patients predicts higher PML risk; fingolimod patients should have annual JCV serology.
• In suspected PML, prompt DMT cessation and MRI within 48 hours can improve prognosis via early immune reconstitution.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misclassifying all new focal deficits in MS as relapse and treating with steroids, risking unchecked viral demyelination.
2. Interpreting VZV IgG seropositivity as acute infection, leading to unnecessary antiviral therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ECTRIMS/EAN Guidelines 2021: Recommend annual JCV index monitoring in fingolimod-treated MS patients; urgent MRI within 48 hours if symptomatic (Level B).
• AAN Practice Guideline 2018 (revised 2020): Advises against high-dose steroids without excluding PML in DMT-associated new deficits; supports JCV serology and neuroimaging (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Neurology boards frequently test PML risk stratification in MS—expect vignettes of DMT, JCV status, and imaging steps. Common formats include “next best step” or “initial diagnostic evaluation” when new neuro deficits arise on immunotherapy.

question_text: Q335. Which condition is associated with features of encephalitis and an ovarian tumor?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is an antibody-mediated, paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis most often seen in young women harboring ovarian teratomas containing neural tissue. NMDA receptors (GluN1 subunit) are ionotropic glutamate receptors critical for synaptic plasticity, memory, and excitatory neurotransmission in the hippocampus and forebrain. Aberrant immune recognition of teratomatous neural antigens leads to IgG1 autoantibodies that crosslink and internalize NMDA receptors, producing subacute neuropsychiatric symptoms, seizures, movement disorders, autonomic dysfunction, and decreased consciousness. Prompt integration of clinical, imaging, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), electrophysiological, and oncological data is required to distinguish this syndrome from other paraneoplastic and primary CNS pathologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDAR encephalitis was characterized by Dalmau et al. (Ann Neurol 2007) in women with ovarian teratomas presenting with psychiatric features, seizures, dyskinesias, and autonomic instability. Pathogenic IgG1 antibodies target the GluN1 subunit, inducing receptor internalization and synaptic hypofunction (Hughes et al., Brain 2010). International consensus diagnostic criteria (Graus et al., Lancet Neurol 2016) emphasize early CSF antibody testing (sensitivity ~100% vs. serum ~85%) alongside MRI (50% show medial temporal T2/FLAIR hyperintensities) and EEG (diffuse slowing or “extreme delta brush,” Schmitt et al. 2012). Pelvic ultrasound or MRI is mandatory in women under 45 to detect ovarian teratomas—tumor resection within 4 weeks of symptom onset correlates with a 94% good recovery rate (Titulaer et al., NEJM 2013). First-line immunotherapies (high-dose corticosteroids, IVIG, plasma exchange) yield improvement in ~53% at 4 weeks; refractory cases benefit from rituximab or cyclophosphamide (Titulaer et al., JAMA Neurol 2013). Multidisciplinary management reduces morbidity and relapse rates.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
• Reason incorrect: Primarily a paraneoplastic cerebellar/brainstem syndrome in children with neuroblastoma, not ovarian teratoma.
• Misconception: Confusing any paraneoplastic movement disorder with encephalitic presentation.
• Differentiator: OMS shows chaotic eye movements and myoclonus without prominent psychiatric or autonomic features.

C. Pilocytic astrocytoma
• Reason incorrect: A benign pediatric glioma presenting as a focal mass lesion, not immune-mediated encephalitis.
• Misconception: Equating brain tumors with paraneoplastic encephalitis.
• Differentiator: Imaging shows a cystic cerebellar mass with mural nodule; no autoantibodies.

D. Medulloblastoma
• Reason incorrect: A malignant pediatric cerebellar embryonal tumor causing hydrocephalus and ataxia, not encephalitic or paraneoplastic.
• Misconception: Assuming all CNS tumors can trigger autoimmune encephalitis.
• Differentiator: Presents with raised intracranial pressure and cerebellar signs; no limbic involvement.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-NMDAR EncephalitisOMS (Paraneoplastic)Pilocytic AstrocytomaMedulloblastoma
Typical Age/GenderYoung women (20–40 yrs)Infants/young childrenChildren/adolescentsChildren (5–10 yrs)
Tumor AssociationOvarian teratomaNeuroblastomaNone (intracerebral origin)None (intracerebral origin)
Clinical PresentationPsychiatric changes, seizures, dyskinesias, autonomic instabilityOpsoclonus, myoclonus, ataxiaFocal deficits, raised ICPCerebellar signs, headache, vomiting
Diagnostic BiomarkerCSF anti-GluN1 antibodies (100% specific)No specific autoantibodyHistology (Rosenthal fibers)Histology (Homer Wright rosettes)
First-Line TreatmentTumor removal + steroids, IVIG, PLEXTumor removal + immunotherapySurgical resectionSurgery + radiotherapy/chemotherapy

Clinical Pearls

- Extreme delta brush on EEG is highly suggestive of anti-NMDAR encephalitis and correlates with severity.
• Early pelvic imaging and rapid teratoma resection within 4 weeks improves functional recovery.
• Always prioritize CSF antibody testing over serum for diagnostic accuracy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misdiagnosing as viral encephalitis and delaying immunotherapy, which worsens outcomes.
• Failing to screen for ovarian teratoma in young women, missing the paraneoplastic trigger.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Graus F et al., Lancet Neurol 2016 (International Consensus). Recommendation: Use CSF anti-NMDAR Ab testing plus clinical criteria for diagnosis (Level B).
2. Titulaer MJ et al., NEJM 2013. Observational multicenter study: Early tumor removal and first-line immunotherapy achieve 94% good outcome; rituximab/cyclophosphamide recommended if no response in 4 weeks (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The GluN1 subunit of NMDAR is densely expressed in hippocampal CA1/CA3 pyramidal neurons and cortical interneurons; antibody-mediated internalization disrupts excitatory–inhibitory balance, producing limbic system dysfunction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies bind extracellular epitopes of the GluN1 subunit, causing receptor crosslinking, internalization, and synaptic depletion without complement activation, leading to reversible synaptic hypofunction rather than fixed neuronal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect in subacute psychiatric changes + seizures + movement/autonomic signs
2. Brain MRI (T2/FLAIR for limbic hyperintensities)
3. EEG (look for extreme delta brush)
4. CSF analysis (pleocytosis, oligoclonal bands) + anti-NMDAR Ab assay
5. Pelvic ultrasound/MRI for teratoma
6. Initiate immunotherapy and tumor resection

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI is normal in ~50%, but may show bilateral medial temporal lobe hyperintensity. Contrast enhancement is minimal.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Methylprednisolone 1 g IV ×5 days, IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days, or PLEX 5–7 exchanges. Second-line: Rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4) ± cyclophosphamide (750 mg/m²).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Paraneoplastic anti-NMDAR encephalitis is a recurrent test topic on neurology and internal medicine boards, often in women with ovarian teratomas presenting with psychiatric and movement abnormalities.

question_text: A 24-year-old female presents with fever, headache, meningeal signs and psychiatric manifestations. CSF HSV PCR is positive, and MRI demonstrates temporal lobe petechial hemorrhages with encephalomalacia. She completes antiviral therapy and initially improves, but two weeks later develops a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. What is the most likely cause of her new seizure?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis causes necrotizing, hemorrhagic lesions in the medial temporal lobes, leading to fever, headache, focal deficits, seizures and psychiatric symptoms. Standard treatment is high-dose acyclovir for 14–21 days. In a subset of patients (often young females), a secondary autoimmune encephalitis—most commonly anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis—emerges 2–4 weeks after the acute viral infection. This post-infectious syndrome presents with new seizures, behavioral changes, memory deficits and movement disorders. Distinguishing relapse of HSV from autoimmune encephalitis is critical, as management shifts from antivirals to immunotherapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis following HSV was first characterized by Dalmau et al. (Lancet Neurol 2008;7:109–117). In reported series, patients develop new psychiatric features, seizures or movement disorders a median of 32 days after HSV onset. CSF shows negative HSV PCR, lymphocytic pleocytosis and anti-GluN1 IgG. MRI may be normal or show nonspecific T2/FLAIR hyperintensities. The 2016 Graus et al. consensus (Lancet Neurol 2016;15:391–404) recommends first-line immunotherapy (high-dose steroids, IVIG or plasma exchange), with early treatment linked to improved outcomes. IDSA’s 2008 HSV encephalitis guidelines (Clin Infect Dis 2008;47:303–327) stress that new neurological decline after antivirals warrants evaluation for relapse (PCR, MRI) versus autoimmune etiology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Expected sequelae of HSV
• Seizures from necrotic scarring (gliosis) are remote symptomatic and typically arise months to years post-infection.
• Misconception: assuming all post-HSV seizures are due to permanent structural damage.
• Differentiator: timing (weeks vs months), CSF PCR negative but autoantibodies positive in autoimmune cases.

C. Recurrent HSV
• Recrudescence presents with fever, altered consciousness and positive HSV PCR in CSF.
• Misconception: equating any post-treatment seizure with viral relapse.
• Differentiator: recurrent HSV shows new hemorrhagic lesions on MRI and PCR positivity.

D. Post-infectious gliosis
• Gliotic scars form over months and cause chronic epilepsy.
• Misconception: calling early post-treatment seizures “gliosis” without considering autoimmunity.
• Differentiator: imaging would show stable encephalomalacia without new lesions; CSF lacks autoantibodies.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-NMDA Receptor EncephalitisRecurrent HSVChronic Gliosis Seizures
Onset2–4 weeks post-treatmentDuring/soon after therapyMonths–years after injury
CSF PCR for HSVNegativePositiveNegative
CSF findingsLymphocytes, anti-GluN1 IgGLymphocytes, ↑ proteinNonspecific
MRINormal or mild T2/FLAIR changesNew hemorrhagic lesionsOld encephalomalacia only
TreatmentImmunotherapyRepeat acyclovirAntiepileptics

Clinical Pearls

1. Suspect post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis in any patient with new seizures or psychiatric symptoms after initial improvement and negative HSV PCR.
2. CSF antibody testing (anti-GluN1) is more specific than serum; send paired samples.
3. Early immunotherapy (steroids, IVIG, plasmapheresis) shortens recovery and reduces relapse.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Automatically re-treating with antivirals for any post-HSV neurological decline without antibody testing.
2. Overlooking the narrow window (2–6 weeks) when autoimmune encephalitis develops, leading to delays in immunotherapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Tunkel et al., IDSA 2008 (LoE B-II): Acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q8h for 14–21 days for HSV encephalitis; reevaluate with CSF PCR and MRI if deterioration occurs.
2. Graus et al., Lancet Neurol 2016 (Expert consensus): Test for neuronal autoantibodies in CSF in suspected autoimmune encephalitis; first-line immunotherapy with high-dose corticosteroids, IVIG or plasma exchange.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Anti-NMDA receptors are densely expressed in the hippocampus and medial temporal lobes—sites preferentially injured by HSV—predisposing to memory deficits, seizures and psychiatric symptoms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

HSV-mediated neuronal necrosis exposes N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor epitopes; breach of immune tolerance leads to generation of anti-GluN1 antibodies, receptor cross-linking, internalization and glutamatergic hypofunction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. New seizures/psychiatric signs post-HSV → MRI brain.
2. CSF analysis: cell count, protein, PCR for HSV.
3. If PCR negative, order CSF neuronal autoantibody panel.
4. Initiate immunotherapy if anti-NMDA IgG positive.

Neuroimaging Pearls

HSV encephalitis: hemorrhagic T1 hypointensities and T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in temporal lobes. Anti-NMDA encephalitis: often normal MRI or subtle medial temporal T2/FLAIR changes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acyclovir: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (renal dosing in insufficiency).
• Autoimmune encephalitis: methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily ×5 days, followed by IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days or plasmapheresis; second-line rituximab or cyclophosphamide for refractory cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. It tests recognition of post-infectious autoimmune complications of viral encephalitis, a frequently tested topic via clinical vignettes requiring differentiation of relapse versus immune-mediated pathology.

question_text: A patient with optic neuritis has an MRI of the spine that shows long-sequence enhancement and is OGB negative. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Optic neuritis often heralds a central demyelinating process; differentiation between multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is crucial.
1. Demyelination targets the optic nerve and spinal cord differently: MS lesions are typically <3 vertebral segments and show oligoclonal bands (OCB) in CSF; NMOSD characteristically produces longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM) >3 segments and is OCB negative.
2. Aquaporin-4 (AQP4) is a water-channel protein on astrocyte foot processes; AQP4-IgG autoantibodies define NMOSD.
3. Early identification of NMOSD directs specific long-term immunotherapy (e.g., eculizumab, inebilizumab) and avoids MS treatments that may exacerbate disease.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Testing for AQP4-IgG is the key diagnostic step when LETM and OCB negativity raise suspicion for NMOSD. The 2015 International Panel on NMO Diagnosis (Wingerchuk et al., 2015) established that seropositivity for AQP4-IgG confirms NMOSD in the presence of a core clinical syndrome (optic neuritis, LETM). Initiating immunotherapy without confirming the underlying antibody status can expose patients to inappropriate MS disease-modifying therapies (e.g., interferon-β), which may worsen NMOSD (Jacob et al., 2012). While high-dose IV steroids treat acute demyelination, they do not establish etiology; plasma exchange is reserved for steroid-refractory attacks (Weinshenker et al., 1999). Deferring to follow-up MRI delays definitive diagnosis and appropriate long-term therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start high-dose steroids
• Acute optic neuritis and LETM warrant IV methylprednisolone, but initiating steroids alone without antibody testing fails to differentiate NMOSD from MS.
• Misconception: treating first, diagnosing later; in NMOSD, specific diagnosis guides long-term management.

C. Refer for plasma exchange
• Indicated only if there is insufficient response to high-dose steroids or in fulminant attacks.
• Differentiates treatment escalation rather than initial diagnostic step.

D. Schedule a follow-up MRI
• LETM is already demonstrated; repeating imaging delays serological confirmation and initiation of targeted immunotherapy.
• Misconception: serial imaging will yield diagnosis, but antibody assays provide definitive etiological classification.

Comparison Table

FeatureMSNMOSDImplication for This Case
Spinal lesion length<3 vertebral segments≥3 vertebral segments (LETM)LETM suggests NMOSD
CSF oligoclonal bands (OCB)Positive in ~85%Negative in ~75%OCB negativity points toward NMOSD
Antibody markerNone specificAQP4-IgG positiveAQP4 testing confirms NMOSD
Acute therapyIV steroids; interferon-β maintenanceIV steroids; immunosuppressantsAvoid MS-specific drugs in NMOSD

Clinical Pearls

- LETM (>3 segments) on spinal MRI has >90% specificity for NMOSD in the right clinical context.
• NMOSD patients often lack CSF OCB but exhibit elevated serum AQP4-IgG titers.
• Early AQP4-IgG testing expedites initiation of B-cell–depleting therapy (e.g., rituximab) and novel complement inhibitors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all optic neuritis with MS and automatically starting interferon-β.
2. Relying on follow-up imaging rather than serology to distinguish demyelinating syndromes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Panel for NMO Diagnosis (2015): Defined AQP4-IgG seropositivity as a core criterion for NMOSD diagnosis (Level C evidence).
• ECTRIMS/EAN Guideline on NMOSD (2018): Recommends first-line testing for AQP4-IgG in LETM or bilateral optic neuritis to guide treatment choice (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The optic nerve and spinal cord are rich in astrocyte foot processes expressing AQP4. In NMOSD, antibody-mediated astrocytopathy leads to necrotizing lesions in these regions, whereas MS primarily targets oligodendrocytes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

AQP4-IgG binds to astrocytic water channels, activating complement and recruiting inflammatory cells. This results in astrocyte injury, secondary demyelination, and necrosis distinct from the oligodendrocyte-centric mechanism in MS.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical syndrome: optic neuritis ± transverse myelitis.
2. MRI brain/spine: assess for LETM.
3. CSF studies: cell count, OCB.
4. Serum AQP4-IgG (and MOG-IgG if AQP4-IgG negative).
5. Initiate acute therapy (IV steroids) and plan long-term immunotherapy based on antibody status.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (≥3 vertebral segments) with central cord T2 hyperintensity and gadolinium enhancement is highly suggestive of NMOSD versus MS, where lesions are shorter and peripherally located.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute: IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days; if no improvement, plasma exchange (5–7 sessions).
Chronic NMOSD: B-cell depletion (rituximab), complement inhibition (eculizumab), or IL-6 receptor blockade (satralizumab).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Questions on demyelinating disorders often test the differentiation between MS and NMOSD, emphasizing AQP4-IgG testing in LETM and optic neuritis to guide targeted therapy.

question_text: In a case of primary progressive multiple sclerosis with typical MRI features and normal cerebrospinal fluid, what is known to increase walking speed?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] - Demyelination in MS disrupts saltatory conduction along central axons, causing conduction block and slowed nerve transmission—key contributors to gait impairment.
• Primary progressive MS (PPMS) is characterized by insidious, unremitting neurological decline (often gait-predominant), typical T2-hyperintense MRI lesions, and may have normal CSF oligoclonal bands in ~25% of cases.
• Therapeutic strategies in MS split into disease-modifying therapies (DMTs, e.g., ocrelizumab) that slow progression, and symptomatic therapies (e.g., dalfampridine) aimed at improving function, such as walking speed.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dalfampridine is a sustained-release formulation of 4-aminopyridine that non-selectively blocks voltage-gated potassium channels exposed on demyelinated axons. By prolonging action potential duration and reducing K⁺ efflux, it enhances conduction across demyelinated segments. In two pivotal phase III, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials (Goodman et al., Lancet Neurol. 2009;8(2):141–151), 35% of treated MS patients (including PPMS and SPMS subgroups) achieved a >20% improvement in timed 25-foot walk (T25-FW) on ≥3 of 4 visits versus 8% with placebo (p<0.001). The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2014 guidelines assign Level A evidence for dalfampridine to improve walking speed in ambulatory MS patients (EDSS 4–7).
Ocrelizumab, a humanized anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, demonstrated a 24% relative risk reduction in confirmed disability progression at 12 weeks versus placebo in the ORATORIO trial (Hauser et al., NEJM 2017;376:209–220), but it does not produce acute functional gains in gait speed. Baclofen, a GABA_B agonist, alleviates spasticity but may exacerbate weakness and sedation, lacking evidence for increased walking speed. Physical therapy improves endurance and balance long term but has not shown the rapid, statistically significant T25-FW improvements seen with dalfampridine in Class I trials.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Ocrelizumab
• Although it slows disability progression in PPMS by B-cell depletion, it does not acutely enhance axonal conduction or increase walking speed.
• Misconception: equating DMT efficacy with immediate functional improvement.

C. Baclofen
• Mechanism: GABA_B receptor agonism reduces spasticity but can worsen muscle strength and cause CNS depression.
• Key difference: spasticity reduction does not translate into faster nerve conduction or gait speed.

D. Physical therapy
• While essential for long-term mobility and balance, no placebo-controlled study has demonstrated acute T25-FW improvements comparable to dalfampridine.
• Pitfall: conflating endurance training benefits with immediate gait-speed enhancement.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismEffect on Walking SpeedLevel of Evidence
Dalfampridine (4-AP)Blocks voltage-gated K⁺ channels, enhances conduction↑ T25-FW by >20% in 35% of patients (p<0.001)Class I RCTs; AAN Level A
OcrelizumabAnti-CD20 B-cell depletionNo acute gait-speed changeClass I RCTs; reduces progression
BaclofenGABA_B agonist reducing spasticityNo improvement; may worsenClass III evidence; symptomatic
Physical therapyExercise, balance, endurance trainingVariable; no acute RCT benefitSystematic reviews; moderate

Clinical Pearls

- Dalfampridine ER 10 mg BID is approved for improving walking speed in MS; avoid in CrCl <50 mL/min and monitor for seizures.
• Always distinguish symptomatic therapies (e.g., dalfampridine, antispasticity agents) from DMTs; they can be used concomitantly.
• Use the timed 25-foot walk as an objective measure before and after initiating dalfampridine to assess responder status.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming that DMT initiation (e.g., ocrelizumab) yields immediate functional gains rather than long-term progression slowing.
• Believing that reducing spasticity with baclofen will necessarily translate into faster gait.
• Overlooking seizure risk associated with elevated plasma levels of dalfampridine, especially in renal impairment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2014 Guidelines on Symptomatic Management in MS
• Recommendation: Dalfampridine is effective to improve walking speed (Level A, Class I evidence).
2. Hauser SL et al., ORATORIO Trial (NEJM 2017;376:209–220)
• Finding: Ocrelizumab reduces confirmed disability progression in PPMS (HR 0.76; 95% CI 0.59–0.98) but does not improve acute gait speed.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Demyelination exposes internodal voltage-gated K⁺ channels along corticospinal and proprioceptive fibers. Unblocked K⁺ efflux hyperpolarizes the axon, slowing conduction. Dalfampridine restores conduction by blocking these channels.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Primary progressive MS features chronic, smoldering axonal loss with less focal inflammation. Demyelinated axons develop conduction block and internodal dysfunction due to redistribution of ion channels.

Neuroimaging Pearls

PPMS MRI often shows fewer brain lesions but prominent spinal cord T2 hyperintensities and atrophy. Normal CSF oligoclonal bands do not exclude the diagnosis in the context of typical MRI and clinical progression.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Dosing: Dalfampridine ER 10 mg twice daily, ≥12 hours apart.
• Contraindications: CrCl <50 mL/min (↑ seizure risk).
• Adverse Effects: Seizure (0.4%), UTIs, insomnia.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
Symptomatic management of MS gait impairment—particularly the use of dalfampridine to improve timed walking—is a high-yield topic frequently tested as a vignette requiring distinction between symptomatic versus disease-modifying treatments.

question_text: A young male patient with a known case of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) on natalizumab developed lower limb weakness and generalized numbness. Laboratory tests show positive anti-natalizumab antibodies, and MRI shows enhanced lesions. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder characterized by perivenular inflammatory plaques in the CNS white matter, especially periventricular regions and spinal tracts. Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4-integrin, preventing leukocyte migration across the blood–brain barrier. Development of neutralizing anti-natalizumab antibodies leads to loss of drug efficacy and new gadolinium-enhancing lesions, manifesting as clinical relapse. Acute MS relapses are defined by new or worsening neurological deficits lasting >24 hours without infection or fever. First-line therapy for moderate to severe relapses is high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone, which stabilizes the BBB, suppresses cytokine production, and accelerates recovery. Second-line therapies, such as plasma exchange, are reserved for steroid-refractory cases. Understanding these principles guides appropriate relapse management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The recommended treatment for an acute MS relapse—regardless of natalizumab failure—is high-dose IV steroids (D). The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline (Goodin et al., 2018; Level A evidence) advises 1 g/day IV methylprednisolone for 3–5 days as first-line for moderate to severe relapses. This regimen reduces inflammation by downregulating proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-1, TNF-α), restoring BBB integrity, and limiting demyelination. Neutralizing anti-natalizumab antibodies confirm treatment failure but do not change acute relapse protocol; long-term management requires switching disease-modifying therapy. Plasma exchange (PLEX) is supported by Class I/II trials (Weinshenker et al., 1999) only when patients fail to improve after a full course of steroids (Level B evidence). IVIG has not demonstrated efficacy in acute exacerbations, and oral prednisolone provides inferior CNS penetration compared to IV formulations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Plasma exchange
• Incorrect because PLEX is second-line for steroid-refractory relapses, not the initial treatment.
• Misconception: believing that antibody removal is first-step upon natalizumab failure.
• Key differentiator: PLEX is indicated only after inadequate steroid response.

B. IVIG
• Incorrect due to lack of randomized trial support for acute MS relapse (no significant benefit in RCTs).
• Misconception: equating immunoglobulin therapy in Guillain-Barré with MS relapse.
• Key differentiator: IVIG does not modulate the T-cell–mediated demyelination in MS.

C. Prednisolone (oral)
• Incorrect as oral glucocorticoids achieve lower CNS concentrations and slower onset than IV.
• Misconception: assuming oral and IV steroid regimens are interchangeable in severe relapse.
• Key differentiator: IV methylprednisolone is the evidence-based route for acute MS exacerbations.

Comparison Table

TreatmentMechanismIndication in Acute RelapseKey Notes
Intravenous steroidsAnti-inflammatory; stabilizes BBBFirst-line moderate–severe relapse1 g IV methylprednisolone daily ×3–5 days
Plasma exchangeRemoves pathogenic antibodies, cytokinesSteroid-refractory relapse5–7 exchanges over 10–14 days; Class I/II evidence
IVIGPolyclonal IgG immunomodulationNot indicatedNo proven benefit; risk of thrombosis, renal issues
Prednisolone (oral)Anti-inflammatory glucocorticoidNot recommended for severe relapseLower CNS bioavailability; slower clinical effect

Clinical Pearls

• Always obtain MRI with gadolinium within 2–3 weeks of symptom onset to confirm active demyelination.
• High-dose IV steroids speed functional recovery but do not alter long-term disability progression.
• In the setting of neutralizing antibodies to natalizumab, discontinue natalizumab permanently and initiate an alternative DMT (e.g., fingolimod, alemtuzumab).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Initiating plasma exchange before a full course of IV steroids in a steroid-naïve relapse.
2. Using IVIG for acute MS relapse based on its efficacy in other autoimmune neuropathies.
3. Assuming oral steroid taper alone suffices for a moderate to severe exacerbation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN 2018 Practice Guideline (Goodin DS et al.): Recommends high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day for 3–5 days) as first-line for moderate to severe MS relapses (Level A evidence).
2. ECTRIMS/EAN 2021 MS Guidelines: Endorse IV steroids for acute relapse and reserve plasma exchange for steroid-unresponsive cases (Grade 1B recommendation).
3. Canadian MS Working Group 2017: Advises against IVIG in acute exacerbations due to lack of efficacy (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the lateral corticospinal tracts within the spinal cord produce lower limb weakness. Concomitant dorsal column involvement leads to generalized numbness and impaired proprioception. Gadolinium enhancement on MRI reflects focal BBB disruption at active demyelinating plaques.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

MS relapses result from perivenular infiltration of autoreactive CD4+ Th1/Th17 cells, CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, B cells, and macrophages, leading to myelin and oligodendrocyte damage. Natalizumab inhibits α4β1 integrin–VCAM-1 interaction to block leukocyte CNS entry; neutralizing antibodies negate this effect.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation of new focal neurological deficit >24 hours
2. Exclusion of pseudo-relapse (infection, fever, metabolic causes)
3. MRI brain/spine with gadolinium to identify enhancing lesions
4. Initiate high-dose IV methylprednisolone for moderate to severe deficits

Neuroimaging Pearls

Gadolinium-enhancing T1 lesions indicate active inflammation and correlate with recent symptom onset. Classic periventricular “Dawson’s fingers” are oriented perpendicular to the lateral ventricles.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IV methylprednisolone (1000 mg/day IV over 3–4 hours for 3–5 days) modulates gene transcription to reduce inflammatory mediator release, stabilize endothelial tight junctions, and promote lesion resolution. Monitor for hyperglycemia, insomnia, mood lability, and infection risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Acute MS relapse management—specifically the stepwise use of high-dose IV steroids followed by plasma exchange if needed—is a frequently tested topic on neurology board examinations, often as a clinical vignette requiring treatment sequencing.

question_text: Q57. A patient presents with a triad of areflexia, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (Miller Fisher syndrome). What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is an acute, immune-mediated neuropathy and a recognized variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome.
• It is characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia (III, IV, VI cranial nerves), gait ataxia (proprioceptive sensory fiber involvement), and areflexia.
• Pathophysiology hinges on anti-GQ1b IgG antibodies that bind to ganglioside GQ1b, abundant on oculomotor nerves, activating complement and causing demyelination at peripheral nerve nodes of Ranvier.
• Clinically, MFS often follows a viral illness by 1–2 weeks and demonstrates albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis. Early immunotherapy alters the course and speeds recovery.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is the first-line therapy for MFS because it neutralizes pathogenic antibodies, blocks Fc receptors, and attenuates complement activation. In a landmark randomized trial of Guillain-Barré variants (French Cooperative Group, NEJM 1997), IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day × 5 days) was as effective as plasmapheresis in accelerating recovery but had a superior safety profile in cranial-nerve-predominant syndromes. The Joint EFNS/PNS guideline (2010) assigns Level A evidence to both IVIG and plasmapheresis in GBS/MFS, but clinical consensus favors IVIG for ease of administration and fewer adverse events in MFS. Corticosteroids have been shown in multiple RCTs (Hughes et al., Brain 2001) to be ineffective or harmful. Supportive care alone leads to protracted recovery and higher morbidity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Plasmapheresis (Plex)
